Imagine having someone's life in the palm of your hands. It's up to you whether you protect it with your saber or... well... do the other thing sabers are for.

mnemonics.meaning: You have a private mouth that's a machine. But you have to keep your machine mouth private because it would scare all the non-machine people around you. Doesn't this kanji look like a machine mouth? Now wouldn't you want to keep that private from the people you know?
mnemonics.reading: To make sure they can't tell what's machine and what's human, you dye (だい) the mouth to make it look like skin. You find dye the same shade as your normal mouth and just slap it on there. Imagine being so afraid that people will find out about your machine mouth that you have to dye it to match a normal human mouth. Oh, when will this discrimination against machine-kind end?!

mnemonics.meaning: The sun lets out one drop, and then another drop. The drops dance together in the air, combine, and when they hit the ground, up sprouts your mother! Picture these two drops of the sun morphing before your very eyes until they look exactly like your dear ol' mum. She's bright and shining like the sun, and she's looking down at you, her big drop-eyes full of tears.
mnemonics.reading: Suddenly your mother points at you and laughs, "Haha (はは)!" She keeps laughing, haha haha haha, over and over. You start to feel uncomfortable. You thought your mother was going to say something sweet or profound or motherly, and instead she's pointing and saying, "Haha," over and over. Yeah. That sounds like my mom.

mnemonics.meaning: The slide is dry at noon. The sun is brightest at noon, so it dries the morning dew off the slide, making noon the perfect time to slide. Picture all the kids out sliding on the slide at noon during their lunch break. It's hot and dry and they're very happy.
mnemonics.reading: Noon also happens to be the time Godzilla (ご) decided to attack for the same reasons: it's dry and kids are using the slide. Watch in horror as Godzilla's giant foot crushes all the kids and their slide at exactly noon. You'd better go...

mnemonics.meaning: Balance a spoon on your pointed fingers and it will always point north. The spoon is like a compass needle and your fingers guide the knowledge your body already has and uses it to point north. That's science, friends! Notice how the fingers radical is a little different here? That's because you're pointing them really hard. Imagine taking a spoon and balancing it on your fingers. Now watch the spoon spin spin spin until it stops and ultimately points north.
mnemonics.reading: You realize that this ability to find north is probably really valuable, so you go to the nearest pawn shop and hock (ほく) it. Even your fingers. Imagine walking out of a pawn shop after hocking your fingers and spoon and realizing that you don't know where you are. Oh, if only you could tell where north was...

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for now first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means now as well. Make sure you know those radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: Right now the condors (こん) are in danger! Not next week, not next year, right now! Haven't you heard that deforestation and pollution are killing all of the condors?! Go outside right now and do something to save the condors. If you don't do something right now there won't be enough time left!

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for old first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means old as well. Note: This "old" does not refer to people. Think of it as "old things" instead. Make sure you know those radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: Old things are misunderstood by the 子s (こ) of the world. *Note:* Come up with a 子 character you can use for all the こ reading mnemonics going forward. This child will show up many times throughout your mnemonic journey, and it will help if you imagine the same character the whole time. Imagine a 子 looking at old things. A record player. A gameboy. A cassette player. Kids just don't get old things. Note: When you see the (古) radical in a kanji, there's a good chance it will use the reading こ.

mnemonics.meaning: The origin radical and the origin kanji are the same! Know your radicals!
mnemonics.reading: The origin of everything can be found in Genji (げん). Genji is the name of the main character in the world's first ever novel, "The Tale of Genji."  Picture him as a rich, pretty boy who cares a ton about his looks and gets along really well with all the ladies. He's also really great at poetry, which helps the lady situation. Genji's origin story is pretty important when it comes to mnemonics and Japanese literature. He's going to keep popping up on your kanji journey, so make sure you remember him!

mnemonics.meaning: You're known to get the ailment evening toe, which is when your toe catches on fire after getting really, really hot (imagine this happening, ouch!). The only way to fix it is to cool your toe down, and the best way to do that is to go outside. After imagining your evening toe overheating, rush outside to fix it. It's the best way to prevent fire toe, which is way worse. In the evening it's nice and cold outside too, so feel this on your skin, and feel the cold air on your toe, which is starting to get some relief.
mnemonics.reading: You go outside (you’re not supposed to be out there at night!) and you’re accosted by a couple of guys. Then, all of a sudden, Guy (がい) Fawkes jumps from the roof above you and takes them out, then starts running. “Guy Fawkes!” you yell after him! If you don’t know Guy Fawkes, you should do a little reading up on him to make this mnemonic make sense. Also, Anonymous People wear a Guy Fawkes mask, if that helps any.

mnemonics.meaning: The fins that fell onto my sword were sliced into two parts. The logic of this story makes a lot of sense - even in the kanji itself the fins are falling onto the sword from above. What happens to things that fall onto swords? They become more than one part.
mnemonics.reading: Now that you've cut the fish, it's time to cut something else into parts. Next on your list is the buns (ぶん) which need to be split up amongst the people. If you'd like to learn the second reading, just think about how fun (ふん) it will be to do this task. Think about the buns (ぶん) as absolutely delicious things you want to eat really bad. If you want to eat the buns, and you taste the buns in your imagination, you'll surely remember that the reading for this kanji is ふん as well.

mnemonics.meaning: You have fins in private. But, you want the world to see them, so you take them public. Picture yourself in private, with fins. You wish others could see them. "That's it," you decide. "It's time to show the world. I'm going to make my fins public!"
mnemonics.reading: You head out into the public where everyone can see your fins, but... things have changed. All people are the same. There are thousands of こういちs walking around, and they all stare at you (though they pretend like they aren't). Remember, whenever we see the reading こう, think of こういち, a founder of WaniKani. We'll keep it consistent, so over time you should develop a character around こういち that you learn to love or hate. How long have you been hiding in private with your fins? The public areas have changed, and all the people have become こういちs. One mother こういち--pushing a baby こういち--looks up and stares at your fins. Now you remember why you never go out in public.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have a bow and a stick you need to pull the two back together to shoot it. If you can't pull it, you won't be shooting anything. Imagine taking a stick and pulling it back into your bow. Imagine how hard you have to pull. This thing is really strong!
mnemonics.reading: When you pull the bow back, your body strains and you feel an immense heat (ひ) rise inside of you. You keep pulling and the heat grows hotter and hotter. Imagine using all your strength to pull on this bow. Imagine the heat rising in your body. There's sweat dripping down your face. It's so hot, but you have to keep pulling!

mnemonics.meaning: The stop radical is the same as the stop kanji. Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: You have to stop because there is a sheep (し) in front of you. You try to walk around the sheep, but it moves to stop in front of you again. Every time the sheep stops you stop too. Imagine the fluffy wool of the sheep, stopping you from moving forward. You can't push past it, no matter how hard you try.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for task first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means task as well. Make sure you know those radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: Today, your task is to eat yogurt (よう). It's nutritious, it's delicious, and I'm telling you to do it, so you have to. A task is basically just something you have to do, so that's what this is. Eat your yogurt. (Gogurt doesn't count, don't @ me.)

mnemonics.meaning: You cut the leaf with your sword into ten thousand pieces! If you can get to ten thousand different pieces, then that means your sword is absolutely perfect. If your sword dulls before you get to ten thousand, you have to throw it away.
mnemonics.reading: Now that you have ten thousand pieces of tiny leaf paper, you decide to turn them into a manga (まん)! Each little leaf piece will become a panel. Carefully draw your manga onto these ten thousand leaf pieces. Maybe you even use your sword again to give them some textured details. You're so creative and talented!

mnemonics.meaning: The canopy you use in private is very wide. You want your private canopy to be wide so you can sprawl out under it is as much as you want. No one's going to come in and tell you to close your legs or sit up straight. So it can be as wide as you like!
mnemonics.reading: You like being wide because it makes you feel like a different person. But not just any person, like a super hero (ひろ)! Picture yourself laying under your wide, private canopy pretending to be a super hero on the ground. You're stretching a nice, wide super hero pose, like you're flying through the sky.

mnemonics.meaning: We have the winter radical and the two radical (though it's sort of slanted). What's two times the winter radical, if radicals are just a part of a kanji? Two times would be enough to create the entire kanji, which is also winter. You could also think, "Winter too" instead of "two." Because, this kanji is in fact "winter too."
mnemonics.reading: Winter is the time of year you give out presents: "one fo' you, one fo'you. And... not you, this one's not fo' you so fu’ you! (ふゆ)! Note, be careful: this kanji is a little different from the radical 夂 though has the same meaning… but don’t let that fool you (ふゆ).

mnemonics.meaning: This word is a single kanji with hiragana attached, though there is no specific clue as to what type of word it is. That means you can usually guess it's a noun, adverb or na-adjective (in this case it's a noun / adverb). The meaning of this word is pretty much the same as the kanji, though, making it fairly easy. The kanji meaning for 少 is few, and the meaning of the vocab form is a little or a few.
mnemonics.reading: Did you know that this word created an English word you probably already know? Have you ever heard someone say "just a skosh"? That's 少し! Hopefully you know this English word and therefore know this Japanese word as well.

sentences: ぎゅうにゅうは、少ししかありません。
There is only little milk.
少ししかのこってないよ。
There are only a few left.
かれのプロポーズは少しあいまいだった。
His proposal was a little vague.

mnemonics.meaning: The アメリカ part is pretty easy so long as you know katakana. It's the word for "America." You know that 人 means "person," so you can figure out that America + Person = American.
mnemonics.reading: Often times, when two kanji come together to form a kanji compound (or jukugo), you use the on'yomi readings. This is similar to that, though instead of another kanji it's a foreign word. This pattern works with almost any country as well. Just add 人 to a country name and you've described the people who live there. You'll see more of these before you're finished here. And since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:  Americans absolutely love their jeans (じん), it's a well-known fact!

sentences: おれはアメリカ人か？
Am I American?
アメリカ人が二人います。
There are two American people.
アメリカ人の女とともだちになった。
I made friends with an American girl.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned when learning the kanji.

sentences: 矢はなん本のこっていますか？
How many arrows are left?
こいのキューピッドが矢をはなとうとしているよ。
Cupid is about to fire an arrow.
ほくべい土人の矢じりがとんできた。
A Native American arrowhead flew towards me.

mnemonics.meaning: This counter is used with some kind of machine or device, usually a fairly large one (so nothing itty bitty). Cars are a good example of this. But it can also be used for things like computers, which were once the size of rooms, but are now nice and small. Thanks technology!
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Be sure to omit the 〜 in your answer as it is only a placeholder for a number.

sentences: バスはなん台いりますか？
How many buses do we need?
し力がよくなるきかいを三台ちゅうもんしました。
I ordered three machines that makes your eyesight better.
あのかねもちしゃちょうはこうきゅうしゃを三台もっています。
The rich company president has three luxury cars.

mnemonics.meaning: イギリス means "Great Britain" or "United Kingdom." So what is a "Great Britain person?" You guessed it — a British person, or Brit.
mnemonics.reading: The first part's reading is just in katakana. The second part is the じん from 人.

sentences: あの鼻すじの通ったイギリス人は、鼻にかかった声で話します。
That British person with the straight nose speaks in a nasal voice.
このイギリス人は、梅ずを飲んだことがないそうです。
Apparently, this British person hasn't tried ume vinegar before.
知らないイギリス人から友達申請が来たよ。
I got a friend request from a Brit I don't know.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned when learning the kanji.

sentences: 大阪市で生まれました。
I was born in Osaka City.
市のあたらしいマスコットキャラクターがけっていしました。
The new mascot of the city has been decided.
きょうとの市バスの中で、はいてしまった。
I puked on a Kyoto city bus.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are the same. This word is a bit broader than cow though, and can also be used to be bull and ox.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you to remember it:  You're leading the cows around the field. To get them to move, you yell out "USH, USH, USH!" (うし) because you have a speech impediment and want to say "MUSH MUSH MUSH." Go ahead and say this out loud, yelling it if you can.

sentences: きょうこさんは牛をかっているらしい。
Apparently Kyoko is raising a cow.
デイブは、牛ですよ。
Dave is a cow.
かの女は、牛がらのドレスをきて、牛どんやに行ってきました。
She came to a gyudon restaurant in a cow-spot patterned dress.

mnemonics.meaning: Do you remember the words 出口 (exit) and 入り口 (entrance) from previous levels? The 口 can be a doorway of some kind. This word is literally "door mouth" but I bet you can figure out that this actually means doorway.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this one is mixed. You get the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, even though it's a combo (jukugo) kanji. Since 戸's only reading is the kun'yomi reading you should know it. Also, you should know the kun'yomi reading for 口 as well from level 1. That means as long as you remember that this is a kun'yomi fest over here, you should be able to read this word. Also watch out for the rendaku (also known as sequential voicing). That just means the く becomes the voiced ぐ.

sentences: 戸口に手ぶくろがおちていました。
A glove was dropped in the doorway.
たまたま、戸口でぬすみぎきしてしまったんです。
I  eavesdropped it at the doorway by accident.
戸口に三枚のトーストがあった。
There were three pieces of toast in my doorway.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 山 means mountain. Add the hiragana びこ to the end and this gives you echo. That's because bee children (bee 子) love echos, especially mountain echos! Imagine baby bees buzzing as loudly as they can and hearing their voices echoing back at them through the mountains. As the kanji suggests, 山びこ is generally used to describe the echo you get if you shout in the mountains. To decribe other types of echo, you can use the katakana word エコー. By the way, there is actually a kanji for the second part of this word, but it's so rare that it's usually written in kana!
mnemonics.reading: You learned this kanji reading when you learned the vocabulary 山.

sentences: 山びこが聞こえる！
I can hear an echo!
山びこがひびいた。
The echos reverberated.
「ヤッホー」と言ったら、「ヤッホー」と山びこが返ってきた。
I said "yoo-hoo" and "yoo-hoo" came echoing back at me.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji 外 alone means "outside." This word means extremity. How can you remember this? Just think of the れ as a "ray of sunshine." Where you are, in the extremity of space, even the れs of the sun cannot be seen. So, when 外 is combined with れ just think of this.
mnemonics.reading: Let's continue the previous story: You're off in the extremity of space and your friend is running low on Vitamin D. He has (はず) to get some sun れs on his skin! How's that supposed to happen with those spacesuits on, though?

sentences: かれはまち外れの小さないえにすんでいます。
He lives in a small house in the outskirts of town.
王女は、きせつ外れのドレスをきていた。
The princess was wearing a dress that doesn't suit the season.
「あたりが出ると、もう一本」とかかれたアイスをかったが、ぜんぶ外れだった。
I bought some ice cream that had, "If you hit, you get another" written on them, but they were all misses.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of the fat? It's the same: fat.
mnemonics.reading: This is the kun'yomi reading of the kanji (because it's a single kanji, all alone with hiragana attached). The part you have to remember is the ふと portion. Let's use a mnemonic.  The fat guy looked down and couldn't see his foot (ふと).

sentences: 山田さんのまゆげはとても太いです。
Yamada’s eyebrows are very thick.
このおみせのめんはおもったより太かったです。
This shop's noodles are thicker than I expected.
おれの母ちゃんは、ちょう太いんだぜ。
My mom is so fat.

mnemonics.meaning: This word begins with an honorific (お), making whatever comes after it more elevated. Then there's 父, which you know means father. Lastly, we have the honorific name ender さん. So this is a nice way to say father. You use it when you're talking to your own dad or talking about him with friends. You can also use this when you're talking about your friends' dads. In more formal settings, you'll want to use 父 (pronounced ちち) to talk about your own dad and お父様 to talk about someone else's dad. Don't worry, you'll learn that last kanji in a few lessons. Until then, it's pronounced, おとうさま.
mnemonics.reading: The part you have to learn to read is the 父 portion. This uses the kun'yomi, which you didn't learn when doing the kanji.  Imagine you are taking your venerable father to とうきょう. He's always wanted to go and this is the trip of a lifetime! Imagine walking through the streets of Tokyo with your Dad, taking in all the sights.

sentences: お父さんはまい日リンゴをたべます。
My father eats an apple every day.
お父さんにだって分からないことはある。
Even your father has something he doesn't understand.
お父さんのねこはかわいい。
My dad’s cat is adorable.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is the polite and humble form of father. You use this when you're talking about your own father to other people, especially if you aren't very close to them.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned when learning the kanji.

sentences: 父がいるから、さびしくありません。
I’m not lonely because my father is here.
わたしの父は、ドイツ人です。
My father is German.
父はうしのちちをしぼるのがうまい。
My father is very good at milking cows.

mnemonics.meaning: This word has a single kanji with hiragana attached, ending in a い. This means you know it's an adjective. What is the adjective form of few? It's also few.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this one is fairly difficult, as it's the kun'yomi reading (you can tell it's kun'yomi because of all the hiragana attached). You have to remember the すく part to remember the reading of this word. Think of it this way:  You have a few of something. This something is suckers (すく). Imagine putting all (three-ish) of them in your mouth at once. How does it taste? Can you taste the flavors from each of the few?

sentences: ひゃくさいまで生きる人は少ない。
There are few people who live to be 100 years old.
りょうりのレパートリーが少ないんです。
I don't know how to cook many things.
びようしさんから、かみのけが少ないとよくいわれます。
I’m often told by hairdressers that I don’t have much hair.

mnemonics.meaning: As long as you know both of the individual kanji meanings, you should be able to put together this one to get five machines.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: たいじゅうけいを五台かいました。
I bought five scales.
あのいえのまえに、パトカーが五台もとまっている。
There are five police cars parked in front of that house.
五台のバンがげきとつしてめりこんだ。
The five vans smashed into each other.

mnemonics.meaning: An "outside person" is a foreigner. This word is fairly common, though it's not super polite, either. It's okay most of the time, but it can be used derogatorily depending on the situation. The more polite version is 外国人 (outside country person) but you won't learn that until you learn the kanji for 国.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use: Who's the foreigner? Well obviously the guy wearing jeans (がいじん)!

sentences: 田中さんのむすめさんは外人さんとけっこんしたんだよ。
Tanaka’s daughter got married to a foreigner.
でんしゃでよっぱらった外人にからまれた。
A drunk foreigner tried to pick a fight with me on the train.
日本人と外人のあしのながさはかなりちがう。
Leg length is quite different between Japanese people and foreigners.

mnemonics.meaning: フランス is "France." So what is a "France person?" That would be a French Person.
mnemonics.reading: You can treat this word and the 人 kanji on the end like jukugo (combo kanji). Usually, in the case of jukugo, you use the on'yomi reading. So here you'll want to remember to use the on'yomi reading for 人. If you want, you can add 人 to the end of any place name to describe the people that live there!

sentences: フランス人のゆうじんができました。
I made a French friend.
二人はアメリカ人で、あとの三人はフランス人です。
Two of them are American and the other three are French.
とてもセクシーなフランス人シェフにあった。
I met a very sexy French chef.

mnemonics.meaning: Normally a single kanji alone like this would mean the same thing as its parent kanji, but in the case of 生 it's a little different (but still related). When you think of something that has life, it's fresh or raw. Think sashimi or sushi, for example. You want that to be as close as possible to life as you can, so you eat it when it's fresh and raw. This word can also be used to describe a live event, like a concert or sporting event.  You'll see this word at the beginning of other words. For example, 生たまご is "raw egg."
mnemonics.reading: This uses one of the kun'yomi readings. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: After eating raw fish, my yoga teacher and I say namaste (なま) to the sushi chef, bowing low to show our appreciation.

sentences: 生のやさいはにが手です。
I don't like raw veggies.
生ビール一ちょう、下さーい。
Give me a draft beer!
ビートルズは生でみれたらいいな〜。
If only I could have seen the Beatles live!

mnemonics.meaning: A person who is a friend is just that, a friend!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 友人のけっこんしきで、とうきょうにいっていました。
I went to Tokyo for my friend’s wedding.
さらい月、アメリカ人の友人が日本にあそびにきてくれます。
An American friend will come to Japan to visit me the month after next.
あにの友人に、こく白された。
My brother’s friend told me he has feelings for me.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:  Look down! You're holding something covered in fur. It's a furry kettle (け)! It's the weirdest kettle you've ever seen, but presumably it keeps the water hot for much longer.

sentences: あしの毛がボーボーです。
My leg hair is bushy.
うちの犬の毛はよくぬける。
Our dog's fur falls off a lot.
今一ばん大切なのはあたまの毛だ。
Right now the most important thing to me is the hair on my head.

mnemonics.meaning: A little woman is a girl or a young lady. This word is generally used to describe someone who's between the ages of about five and eighteen.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: その少女は、ゆうめいなアイドルです。
That young lady is a famous idol.
久しぶりに、天才少女ゴルファーがあらわれました。
A genius girl golfer has appeared for the first time in a long time.
犬と少女が、はまべをかけていった。
The dog and the little girl ran on the beach.

mnemonics.meaning: A public task is going to be government business. You have to think of this public as government to know the meaning of this word easily.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 今、公用でパリにきています。
I’m coming to Paris now on official business.
これは公用のアカウントです。
This is an official account.
おれたちがぬすむのは公用のかねだ。
We’re gonna steal government money.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it's supposed to use the kun'yomi reading. But, there is no useful kun'yomi reading for this kanji, so even the single kanji vocab word version uses the on'yomi reading, which you've already learned!

sentences: わたしはこのえいがを三かい半みました。
I’ve watched this movie three and a half times.
JLPTまであと一ヵ月半しかありません。
There is only a month and a half left until the JLPT.
かの女は半じゅくたまごのようにかわいいね。
She is as cute as a half-cooked egg.

mnemonics.meaning: You have half a part. Half a part is still half, right?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: この本を半分までよみました。
I’ve read halfway through this book.
このクラスのがくせいの半分は女子です。
Half of this class's students are girls.
ざっくり日本人の半分ぐらいは、にんじゃです。
Roughly half of all Japanese people are ninjas.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:  Imagine a giant heart sitting in a rowing boat. It's also drinking cocoa. Focus on all three of these parts and associate them into one story / memory. Once you've done that, sing the "cocoa row" (こころ) song! I don't know what that song is, but I want you to make one up and actually sing it, out loud. If you do, I bet you won't forget this word's reading too easily.

sentences: せつなさで、心がしめつけられた。
My heart constricted with longing.
おもわず心の中でさけんでしまった。
I couldn't help shouting in my mind.
もしアンパンマンがれいこくな心をもっていたらどうしよう。
I wouldn’t know what to do if Anpanman had a cruel heart.

mnemonics.meaning: Think back to the old old olden days. Back when decisions were made with swords. A big cut is going to be important. Just imagine a couple samurai squaring off, then charging, then making one big cut. It's the most important thing they'll do in their lives (if they live!).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: これは、メアリーが大切にしている人ぎょうです。
This is the doll that Mary treats with a great deal of care.
そばにいてくれる友人やこい人、かぞくを大切にした方がいいですよ。
You should cherish your friends, partner, and family who stand by you.
大切なしょるいときくと、いつも中みをみたくなる。
Whenever I hear that a document is very important, I always want to look at what’s inside.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. When this kanji is a word on its own, it's actually very often written in hiragana. Still, the kanji version of the word is worth knowing, too!
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: There's something inside and you wanna get to what's within. Look inside. Ooh, cheese (うち)! Your favorite. Ooh cheese, how I love you.

sentences: はこの内がわをピンクいろにぬってください。
Please paint the inside of the box pink.
てきは内にあり。
There is an enemy within.
内にひめたおもいを、日きにつづった。
The thoughts I hide inside myself were spelled out in my diary.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 戸をたたかないでください。
Please don’t knock on the door.
うちのねこは戸をカリカリするのがすきです。
My cat likes scratching the door.
この戸は立てつけがわるい。
This door opens and closes hard.

mnemonics.meaning: When you see a katakana word, it's a safe bet that it is a foreign loan word from somewhere else. This one's interesting, because it combines katakana and kanji! The first marble came to Japan from Portugal, so the ビー part of the word is short for "vidro," which means "glass" in Portuguese. Anyway, don't get thrown off by that ビー. Maybe just imagine that your favorite marble is black and yellow like a bee.
mnemonics.reading: If you know katakana as well as the reading that you learned when you learned the kanji 玉, you should be able to read this. Just watch out for the rendaku.

sentences: ビー玉をつかってゲームをしましょう。
Let’s play a game that uses marbles.
アメリカではまいとし一月にビー玉をつかったゲームが上手なフランス人がつどうコンテストがあります。
In America, there is a contest every January where French people who are good at marbles gather.
かれは、けっこんのあかしに一つぶのビー玉をくれた。
He gave me a single marble as proof of our marriage.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is the polite and humble form of mother. You use this when you're talking about your own mother to other people, especially if you aren't very close to them.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but this is the reading you learned with the kanji. Just remember, your mother is a terrible person and won't stop laughing at you: "HA HA HA HA HA!"

sentences: 母はタクシーにのりました。
My mother got in a taxi.
いもうとは、どんどん母ににてきました。
My younger sister is getting to look like our mother more and more.
母はとうふとふぐがすきだ。
My mother likes tofu and fugu.

mnemonics.meaning: This word starts with お which makes it more polite. Then, there's the kanji 母 which you know means mother. Last, there's the honorific さん which further adds respect (to the mother). So, this is the nice way to say mother. You use it when you're talking to your own mom or talking about her with friends. You can also use this when you're talking about your friends' moms. If you need to talk about someone's mother that you don't really know, or you aren't close to, you'll want to use お母様, instead. Don't worry, you'll learn that last kanji in a few lessons. Until then, it's pronounced, おかあさま. Kay?
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. You have to remember the かあ portion. Here's a mnemonic to help you to remember it:  What does your super nice mother do for you (this is why you're so polite to her!)? She drives you all around in her car (かあ) taking you wherever you need to go... soccer, kendo, whatever. What a nice mother you have!

sentences: お母さんはどこ？
Where’s mom?
ひこうき代なら、お母さんが出してあげるよ。
I'm your mother, so I can pay for your flight for you.
お母さんのはなげはながい。
My mom’s nose hair is long.

mnemonics.meaning: The city stand is municipal in nature. Municipal means "of or relating to a city or its governing body", and this vocabulary means just that. Or just city. City is fine too.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: そぼは市立びょういんに入いんしています。
My grandmother is hospitalized at the municipal hospital.
市立としょかんまでのみちをおしえてください。
Please tell me the direction to the municipal library.
大さか市立大がくのまえでさか立ちをした。
I stood on my head in front of Osaka City University.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:  You're going to the far north where it's very cold (north pole, perhaps?). One of the most important things you bring with you is a survival kit (きた).

sentences: えきの北には、びょういんがあります。
There is a hospital on the north side of the station.
北ちょうせんが又ミサイルをはっしゃした。
North Korea launched a missile again.
北アメリカのゆうれいはとてもこわい。
The ghosts in North America are so scary.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:  What'll you drink now? I'll have a Zima, ima. Say "ZIMA IMA" ten times fast.

sentences: 今、しんぶんをよんでいます。
I’m reading the newspaper right now.
おれは今までなにをしていたんだ。
What was I doing until now?
今から、ヘルメットにおはようといいます。
Now I’m going to say good morning to my helmet.

mnemonics.meaning: When you see this on a number, for example ７人 or ３人, you're using it to count people. Just remember, both 一人 and 二人 have alternative readings. From 3 and up it's just the number plus にん, like this. ５人 is ごにん, １０人 is じゅうにん, etc. This is the counter for people, which makes this word the number of people.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the にん reading of this kanji. Just think of a number of people, all ninjas, standing there as you count them out.

sentences: ぜんぶで十人いました。
There were 10 people, altogether.
トーフグにはなん人のしゃいんがいますか？
How many workers are in Tofugu?
わたしは三人子どもがいます。
I have three children.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 大人 means "adult?" Well this is the adjective version of that. The I-adjective (see how it ends in い?). What adjective do adults want to be able to use for their own kids? They want to say they are obedient, quiet kids!
mnemonics.reading: You already learned this reading when you learned 大人! You should be able to read this too!

sentences: さとうさんの犬は、とても大人しいです。
Satou’s dog is very obedient.
なんなのアイツ。がっこうでは大人しいいんキャのくせに。
What's with that guy? He's just a quiet nerd at school.
大人しい子どもだったよ。
He was a quiet kid.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of old? It's also old, ancient, or out-of-date. This word is used for things like clothes, food and friendships, but not for people! So a 古い友人 (old friend) is someone you've been friends with for a long time, not an elderly friend.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji with some hiragana attached, it's going to use the kun'yomi reading. You learned the on'yomi when learning the kanji portion, so let's use a mnemonic to help you with the reading of this word:  If you're old, you're also full (ふる) of memories. And you're probably full of old secrets. And you're full from old people food.

sentences: そのふくは古いので、もういりません。
Those clothes are old, so I don’t need them anymore.
古いものにしがみついていては、あたらしいものをうけとることができません。
If you hold onto old stuff, you can't get anything new.
ガレージで、古いパンツをみつけた。
I found an old pair of underwear in our garage.

mnemonics.meaning: Ten ten thousands is equal to one hundred thousand.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: パチンコで十万円かちました。
I won one hundred thousand yen at pachinko.
このアイフォンは、十万六千九ひゃく円でした。
This iPhone cost me 106,900 yen.
ウォッカをのむと、すう十万でん子ボルトものエネルギーがみなぎってくる。
Whenever I drink vodka, I get pumped full of hundreds of thousands of electron volts.

mnemonics.meaning: As long as you know the two kanji that make up this word, you should be able to figure out the meaning of this word as well.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: このテレビは、一台四万九千円です。
These televisions are forty-nine thousand yen each.
今はパソコン一台でかせぐじだいですからね。
We're living in an era where you can make a living with a single computer.
タクシーを一台よんでください。
Could you call me a taxi?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji for person and life combined makes you think about human life. What is your human life like?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 and 生 both have two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you: Your life boils down to just two things: jeans and a saber (じんせい). Your whole life, that's all you've ever needed, jeans and a saber. What are you, some kind of American pirate?

sentences: 人生ってすばらしい。
Life is wonderful.
人生オワタ ＼(＾o＾)／
My life is over. ＼(＾o＾)／
人生はバナナのようなものさ。どれだけながいのかだれもしらないのさ。
Life is like a banana, you never know how long it will be.

mnemonics.meaning: First we have a katakana word, so it's safe to assume that it's a loan word. Like many loan words, it comes from English. Say it out loud and what do you have? That's right, "table". Then comes the particle の, which joins two nouns together. Finally we have 上, which you learned means "up" or "above". Put all of these pieces together and we have a phrase meaning on the table or tabletop!
mnemonics.reading: In this phrase, 上 is a standalone word, so it uses the same reading that you learned when you learned the vocabulary. Easy to stay on top of that one, right?

sentences: 本はテーブルの上にあります。
The book is on the table.
テーブルの上にグラスを三つおいてください。
Please put three glasses on the table.
さっき、テーブルの上をきれいにしたよ。
I cleaned the table earlier.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. When it's used as a prefix, it takes on the related meaning of ex- or former.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:  You're trying to trace a person back to their origin so you can learn more about them. You finally get there - it's a castle. The problem is that it's surrounded by a huge moat (もと) and you can't get past it because the drawbridge is up. Feel the frustration of this. Think about your goal and how close you are to getting to it if it wasn't for this lousy moat.

sentences: きのう、元つまにあってきました。
Yesterday, I ran into my ex-wife.
元のきじはけされてしまいました。
The original article was deleted.
元は月の出しんなんです。
I’m originally from the moon.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:  You look outside, it's totally frozen. You throw salt (そと) outside to melt the ice.

sentences: 外でまちましょう。
Let’s wait outside.
ねこたちは、まどの外にいるとりをジーッとみています。
The cats are staring at the bird outside of the window.
今日は一日中外であくびをしていた。
I kept yawning outside all day today.

mnemonics.meaning: This word has the same meaning that you learned with the kanji: part, or portion. By extension, it can also mean content, as in "alcohol content" because that's the portion of alcohol in a drink. This word is used for fractions, too, as in one third or one quarter. Again, you can see how this links to "parts" and "portions", right?
mnemonics.reading: This word is usually combined with other words, which is probably why this single kanji vocab word uses the on'yomi instead of the kun'yomi. If you know the kanji reading, you know this vocab's reading as well, but the reading is different depending on the meaning: If it means part or portion, it's read ぶん. Probably because your buns come in two parts. Ohoho.

sentences: その玉ねぎは女王の分だ。
That onion is the queen's portion.
このウィスキーのアルコール分は四十パーセントです。
The alcohol content of this whisky is forty percent.
この市はシアトル市の3分の1の大きさです。
This city is one-third the size of Seattle.

mnemonics.meaning: The name of the city (シアトル／しあとる) with a 市 attached to it means it is "the city of ____." You can do this with any city (try it out on your hometown!). So this word means Seattle, or more specifically City of Seattle.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses on'yomi reading, which you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 今はシアトル市にすんでいます。
I live in Seattle now.
わたしのお母さんは、シアトル市でそだちました。
My mother grew up in Seattle.
あなたのへんがおしゃしんを、シアトル市におくります。
I will send that funny picture of you to Seattle.

mnemonics.meaning: The combination of kanji doesn't make perfect sense, but it's alright. Take something that's middle old and you have something that's used or secondhand. It's not 100% old yet... it's still in the middle, meaning you can give it to someone else to use, like your younger siblings.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 中古ですが、ベンツをかいました。
It’s used, but I bought a Benz.
このあたりは、中古ショップがじゅうじつしています。
There are a lot of secondhand stores in this area.
中古のかぐのような人とはけっこんしたくない。
I don’t want to get married to someone who is like a piece of used furniture.

mnemonics.meaning: When something is in the middle of an action but it's stopped, this means it's put into suspension. Imagine getting frozen while you're running. It's kind of like that.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: やきゅうのしあいは、あめで中止になりました。
The baseball game was called off due to rain.
ざんねんですが、このきかくはいったん中止することになりました。
Sorry, but it was decided that this project will be canceled for now.
たのしみにしていた生ほうそうが中止になった。
The live show I had been looking forward to was canceled.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This one uses the on'yomi reading, which you've learned from the kanji already!

sentences: なにも用がない。
I have nothing to do.
なにかご用ですか？
Do you need me for something?
用もないのにでんわしてくんじゃねーよ。
Don’t call me unless you have a reason.

mnemonics.meaning: If you know the two kanji separately, you should be able to put them together to form the meaning of this kanji.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: パソコンを十台ちゅう文しました。
We ordered ten computers.
ぼうはんカメラを十台せっちしました。
We installed ten surveillance cameras.
たんじょう日にはでんたくが十台ほしい。
I want ten calculators for my birthday.

mnemonics.meaning: When a vocab word is a single kanji without okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it usually has the same meaning as the kanji it's spawned from. If you know the kanji meaning you'll also know the vocab meaning. It's ten thousand!
mnemonics.reading: When a vocab word is a single kanji with no okurigana, it usually uses the kun'yomi reading. Numbers are an exception to this. Numbers use the on'yomi reading, which you've already learned by learning the kanji's reading! How nice!

sentences: 日本へのひこうきだいは、十万五千円でした。
The plane ticket to Japan cost 105,000 yen.
まいとしコウイチは、バレンタインデーに万たんいのチョコレートをもらいます。
Every year Koichi receives tens of thousands of chocolates on Valentine's Day.
ごしゅうぎのそうばは大たい三万円です。
The estimate on a congratulatory gift is approximately 30,000 yen.

mnemonics.meaning: When you have one ten thousand you just have ten thousand. In Japanese, though, you specify how many ten thousands you have, though (which is weird in English, but should make sense if you think about it).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: わたしのぜんざいさんは一万円です。
Ten thousand yen is all I have.
一万RTいったら、こく白します。
If this gets ten thousand retweets, I'll confess my love.
ちくしょう！にせの一万円さつをつかまされた。
Crap! I was cheated into accepting a fake 10,000 yen bill.

mnemonics.meaning: The now month is actually this month.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 今月は大切なテストがあります。
There's an important test this month.
今月の十日までにやってください。
Please do this by the tenth of this month.
今月は、シアトル市にいます。
I'll be in Seattle this month.

mnemonics.meaning: Since this is a kanji with hiragana attached that ends with an う sound, you know that this word is a verb. What's the ultimate verb version of the kanji 生? That would be to be born, the very beginning of life as we know it!
mnemonics.reading: You have to remember the う part of this word to read it. To remember that, let's use a mnemonic:  Just imagine someone being born. All they do is scream: UUUUUuuUuuUUUuuuUUUuu (う) the whole time. Go ahead and imagine yourself being born and doing the same thing. Say UUUuuUUuuu out loud to help you to remember.

sentences: 日よう日、ヤンさんの子どもが生まれました。
On Sunday, Yang’s child was born.
マイケルせん手の、力づよいフルスイングから生まれるホームランのかずかずをごらんください。
Please watch these home runs produced by the strong swings of a pro player named Michael.
生まれたばかりの子どもに、さけをのませるな。
Do not make a newborn baby drink alcohol.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cut, and the verb form of that is to cut.
mnemonics.reading: When you think to cut something, what do you think about cutting? One thing is cutting down a tree, which is also known as 木, or き. You きる a き.

sentences: つぎに、かみをハサミで切ります。
Next, you will cut the paper with your scissors.
いとを切るはさみをさがしています。
I'm looking for scissors that cut thread.
うっかりかみのけをみじかく切りすぎちゃったけど、そのあといぜんよりもよくナンパされるようになった。
Even though I accidentally cut my hair shorter than I intended, more people have been flirting with me since.

mnemonics.meaning: The now day is what day? Oh, it's today.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is a complete exception, though the word itself is incredibly common and useful. When you think of "today" think about what you have to do today for work. You have to work in one of those mall kiosks (きょう). Just think about how sad you are that you have to do this today. What a crummy day. It's sunny outside and you're stuck in a mall manning this hermit crab kiosk. Note: This reading mnemonic is pretty far away from the actual reading, as far as reading mnemonics go. Use this to get yourself close, and then use your own brain grapes to get the rest of the way there. This one won't be as easy as most of the others, but do some good old fashioned memorization and you should be okay. I won't ask you to do this much, fortunately. :)

sentences: 今日のしゅくだいは、二十一ページの二ばんです。
Today’s homework is question two on page twenty-one.
今日はいつもよりうり上げが少ない。
Today's sales are less than usual.
あら、今日が私のたん生日だったんですか？
Oh, was today my birthday?

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji 外 means outside, and the meaning of this verb is somewhat related. It means to disconnect something. Think of it like this, if you disconnect a plug from a socket, you are taking the plug "outside" of the socket, right? Depending on the context, this verb can also mean to miss something (like the target during archery practice), to remove something, or to exclude something. This is a transitive verb. That means it takes a direct object. You disconnect something, like a plug, or remove something, like your dog's leash. It's worth mentioning that most verbs ending in す are transitive, so you'll start seeing this pattern as you learn more!
mnemonics.reading: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be a kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this one yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you're going to disconnect something, it has (はず) to be the right thing! Don't go disconnecting the wrong plug, you'll cause no end of trouble!

sentences: コンセントを外したら、出口から出てください。
Once you disconnect the plug, please use the exit.
またターゲットを外してしまった。
I missed the target again.
キョーコをチームから外した。
We excluded Kyoko from the team.
エンジンを外しましょう。
Let's remove the engine.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fat so the verb form of that is to get fat.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You have to learn the ふと portion of this word to be able to read it. Here's a mnemonic to help you:  You're getting fat so quickly that you can see your body expanding. You look down - at first you can see your foot (ふと) but then a second later you can't. You can't see your foot because you're getting fat, even when you stick your foot way out. What's going on?

sentences: さいきん、たべすぎで少し太りました。
I’ve gotten a little fat from overeating lately.
たべても太らない人がうらやましい。
I envy people who don't get fat even though they eat a lot.
太れば太るほど、わたしはおなかがすく。
The fatter I get, the hungrier I become.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pull and the verb version vocab means to pull. This word has other meanings too! When you pull numbers away from other numbers, what you're really doing is subtracting them. That's why this word also means to subtract. And when you pull something towards you, that's to attract it.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. The reading (ひ) is the same as the one you learned for the kanji, meaning you should already know it!

sentences: 十引く四は六です。
Ten minus four equals six.
どうせ、女のきを引くためにいってるだけでしょう。
He probably says that stuff just to attract attention from girls.
引きがねを引いて、フライパンをうった。
I pulled the trigger and shot the frying pan.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.  The kanji itself means wide, and the verb version is what happens when you try to make something wider. How do you make something wider? That's right, you have to spread something, to unfold something or to open something up. All of those actions will make a thing wider! This is a transitive verb. That means it takes a direct object. You spread something. Like a newspaper, or a cloth on a table.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, but here's a reminder mnemonic to help you: You are going to spread something. What are you going to spread? How about your arms, so that you can fly into the sky like the super hero (ひろ) that you are! Most heroes can fly when they spread their arms wide!

sentences: 日本にそのウィルスを広げたのは水だった。
It was water that spread the virus in Japan.
大人三人でブランケットを広げた。
Three adults unfolded a blanket.
中に入ってすぐ本を広げた。
As soon as I went inside, I opened the book.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stop and the verb vocab version of that is to stop something. This particular word is when you're stopping something (i.e. doing the action of stopping it).
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You need to stop something from moving. Maybe a car... or a door... or a person... whatever you want. To stop this thing, you throw out your toe (と), getting it smashed in the process. Imagine it bleeding and swelling up. How much it hurts! You put your toe out to stop this big thing, what a mistake!

sentences: おんがくを止めてください。
Stop the music please.
三びょうかんいきを止めてください。
Please hold your breath for 3 seconds.
かれがはしりさるのを止めるひつようがある。
We need to stop him from running away.

mnemonics.meaning: This word means to understand, which might surprise you if you remember that the kanji 分 means "part" or "parts." Think of it this way: to understand something you have to break it down into its parts to see how it works. Watch out, though, because whereas in English you understand something, in Japanese the thing you understand is the grammatical subject (it's doing the action). So, a more literal meaning for this is to be understandable. In other words, there's no object, and 分かる is intransitive, meaning it happens on its own. The かる ending is a hint, because verbs with かる as okurigana (kana added to the kanji) are usually intransitive.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You scream "WAHHHHHH" (わ) in terror and "CAAAR!!!" (か) as you careen down the freeway. Your dad is driving like a maniac and almost hit another car! "WAAH CAAAR!!!" (わか) you scream again. If only he understood your terror!

sentences: おいしいかどうか分かりません。
I don’t know if this tastes good.
分かるような、分からないような。
I kind of got it, but I am not sure if I understood all of it.
日本ごは分かりますか？
Do you understand Japanese?

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means task or use. You can think of this verb as a more formal way to say to use, and that is to utilize.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you to learn the もち portion of もちいる:  What will you utilize to get the job done? You have mochi (もち) in your hand, so you'll use that. Now go think of some kind of imaginary task you'll complete with mochi, making it as ridiculous as possible.

sentences: トーフグににたなまえを用いるものがいます。
There is a person who uses a name similar to Tofugu.
北ちょうせんは、かくへいきをおどしに用いる。
North Korea uses nuclear weapons to threaten others.
えをかくために用いるふでで、かの女をくすぐった。
I tickled her with a brush used for painting.

mnemonics.meaning: When you have two ten thousands, you have twenty thousand.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: このぶどうは二万円もしました。
These grapes were 20,000 yen!
二万フォロワーおめでとうございます。
Congratulations on twenty thousand followers!
二万ドルかけるよ。
I will bet twenty thousand dollars.

mnemonics.meaning: When you combine these two kanji, you should be able to see how it forms the word two machines.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: どうしてけいたいを二台もっているんですか。
Why do you have two cell phones?
コウイチの母のいえには、ピアノが二台ある。
There are two pianos at Koichi's mom's house.
うちのトイレにはテレビが二台しかない。
There are only two televisions in our bathroom.

mnemonics.meaning: This starts with another katakana word, so you can assume that it's a loan word. This one also comes from English. Can you figure out what it means? That's right, "bed". Then comes the particle の, which joins two nouns together. Finally, we have 下, which you learned means "down" or "below". Put these elements together and you get below the bed, under the bed or beneath the bed. What's under your bed?
mnemonics.reading: 下 is a standalone word here, so it uses the same reading that you learned when you learned the vocabulary.

sentences: ベッドの下には2000さつのマンガがある。
There are 2000 manga under my bed.
ベッドの下はまったくそうじしないでしょう。
You never clean under your bed, do you?
ベッドの下にかくれてぜんぜん出てこない。
I'm going to hide under the bed and never come out.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading, but it can be either that or the on'yomi reading, depending on the context. You haven't learned the kun'yomi reading for 方 yet, so there's a mnemonic to help you: You need to go a certain direction. How do you get there? By jumping into a catapult (かた) and shooting yourself the right way. Need to get a particular direction fast? Consider the catapult next time.

sentences: どちらの方がすきですか。
Which one do you prefer?
あちらの方に行ってください 。
Please go that direction.
かの女のわらい方がきらいだ。
I don’t like the way she laughs.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of wide? It's also wide.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is the same as the reading you learned in the kanji section: ひろ, making this ひろい.

sentences: 友だちのへやは、広くてきれいです。
My friend’s room is spacious and clean.
あのフランス人はおでこが広い。
That French person has a wide forehead.
すげー広いな！
Wow, this place is huge!

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is the same as the kun'yomi reading you learned for the kanji, meaning you should know both!

sentences: ことしの冬は、ゆきがたくさんふりました。
It snowed a lot this winter.
きょねんの冬にかいたえです。
It's an illustration I drew last winter.
冬をなめるといたい目にあうぞ！
Don’t make light of winter or you’re sure to have a painful experience.

mnemonics.meaning: The の particle makes it so the 人 belongs to the 女. Basically, this literally means "a woman person" or "a person of woman." It's a more polite way to say plain old woman, though, so all you have to remember is that.
mnemonics.reading: This word is actually two separate words combined with a particle. So, since you treat them like separate words, you read each of them with the kun'yomi readings (they are both single kanji words all alone). That being said, in level 1 you learned about the vocab readings for these separate words, so use that knowledge to remember the reading for this word as well.

sentences: わたしは女の人にいじめられた。
I was bullied by a woman.
そのカフェは女の人だらけでした。
The cafe was full of women.
女の人としゃべるのが苦手です。
I’m not good at talking to women.

mnemonics.meaning: See the mouth and teeth of this alligator, which is facing to the right? You wouldn't want to get your hand stuck in there, that's for sure.
See how tall the stalks are with little bushy things at the top? It kind of looks like bamboo, if you use your imagination.

You'll have to complete the line on the right side in your mind, but see the rectangle bed and the pillows? This is totally a bed. That missing line is where you pulled back the sheets when you got up this morning.
Doesn't this look like someone on their knees, holding their hands out (clasped) and begging for something (money, their life, etc.)? That's why this radical is known as the beggar.
There is a cross growing out of this stool. It's branching off of it, if you will. The tree that this stool was made of is coming back to life in the form of a branch.
Doesn't this look like a top-down view of the frame of a car? There are the rods that make up the base of the car and things for the wheels to go on. That's why this radical is the car radical.

This radical looks like a person with a long dress or train running behind them. That's because it's a bride or groom going to their wedding ceremony! You usually have to wear a long dress or a cape if you're at a ceremony. So when you see this radical, think of all the different ceremonies you might have to go to in your life and what you'll need to wear.
See the cliff? It's facing towards the west. What ocean is to your west? That's the direction this cliff is facing.

This radical is a bit more elaborate than the eye, though similar. In fact, if you go blind, your ears become one of your new senses of sight, which is why this is like another, somewhat modified, eye. You'll even notice little lines sticking out of the eye. That's because ears stick out more than eyes (目), which is why this radical is the ear radical.
This radical is shaped kind of like a dam. See the wall and the water pushing over the top? If this radical is a dam, then it must create a ton of energy as well!

See the little things sticking out of the ground? Those little things are pretty little flowers. You know they're flowers and not, say, grass, because they're spaced out. You'll learn grass later, and it will be less spaced out, but somewhat similar to this, so keep that in mind!
Do you see the dude doing a flying dragon kick to the right? What does he hit the target with? Obviously it's his foot.

Sure, this forehead is a bit square, but that's because it's Frankenstein's Monster's forehead. Also, did you notice that this is just the top part of the head (冂) radical? This is just the forehead part of that!
Can you see the horns? You could put these horns on anything. Donkeys, people, monkeys, and so on. That's exactly what we'll be doing when we learn kanji that have horns too.

There is something private in your mouth. You're keeping it private because you don't want other people to judge you. Why? Because it's an insect. You like to eat insects, but society seems to think it's wrong. Don't worry, friend. Someday the rest of the world will embrace eating insects like you have.

This radical technically means person (like 人), but we're going to shift the meaning a little bit. It's kind of like the person radical, but it's taller and skinnier, standing above the rest of those peons. That's why this is a leader, not a regular old person.
The leader (ｲ) radical has a little something extra on top of him, holding him down, holding him back. It's causing him to wait... it's causing him to loiter.
This king has a drop of water floating above his head. That's because he's not just a king, he's the master of water. Master of elements. Master of ALL THINGS!
Have you ever used one of those math compasses? This looks just like one of those because this is the measurement radical. Compasses are used to measure things, just like this.
If you see this radical in a kanji, you'll want to think of the opposite of whatever other radicals there are. It looks a lot like "below," but guess what? It's not the below radical. It's just not.
Obviously, this looks just like the good ol' 3.14 something-something all people are supposed to learn about. It's the math symbol that has to do with circles... pi!
This is a few plates drying on a rack. They're stacked together in a line. Imagine reaching out and grabbing one of those plates for yourself.
There are some legs and fins under the dirt. Imagine yourself looking at all of these severed limbs... there's blood everywhere. No matter how deep you dig, everything is stained red.

Not to be confused with a rice paddy (田). This is just raw rice, like the grain that grows out of the ground when rice is raw and fresh. When rice is particularly ripe, it'll kind of look like this at the top of the stalks. See the long leaves with the little rice tufts at the top? That's why this radical is "rice."
This is a roof. You know it's a roof and not a forehead because there's a little chimney sticking out of the top. And foreheads definitely don't have chimneys.

The samurai radical looks a lot like the dirt radical. The difference is in the top horizontal line. For samurai, the top is longer because he's holding swords. Dirt can't really hold anything because its arms are too short. So when you see this radical, think: long arms for some long swords. That's a samurai!
There's an eyeball on top of some legs. When your eyes get taken places (on legs, in this case), your eyes are seeing those things. That's why this radical means see.

There's a giant eye on top of some fins. Imagine this giant eye to be on top of a clam or a mussel. It has little fins, which it runs around on, escaping from your every attempt to capture it. That's why this is the shellfish radical.
On the ground there are a bunch of spikes coming out. You wouldn't want to step on those now, would you?
This looks just like the katakana character for ne. Ne for necromancer! That makes this a spirit, brought back from the grave. OooooOOoooOoo!

There is something small in some poop. You lean in, carefully pull it out, and realize it's a thread. Why is there some thread in this small poop? Because it's cat poop. And cats love to eat thread when you aren't looking. And floss and hoodie strings and mouse tails. But this poop just has thread in it.

Do you know how the bottom of an umbrella is shaped? It has a hook that curls around for the handle. So when you see this radical, you should think of the bottom of an umbrella, which will help you remember that it means umbrella.

There are no circles in kanji, remember? So imagine that these angles are really circles. A little circle in a big circle, with a line running through them. Why, it's the world. The world looks just like this, with continents on the globe and a line is the equator. Can you see it?
The bamboo radical and the bamboo kanji are exactly the same! Just make sure you know your radicals!
mnemonics.reading: There's a little bamboo shrub sitting there, holding onto a lollipop. Because you're bigger than the bamboo shrub, you just take (たけ) it from the bamboo, causing it to cry. Of course, focus on the absurdity of a bamboo shrub that can cry and eat a lollipop. Also, think about how mean you are to take the lollipop away from a defenseless bamboo shrub in the first place!

mnemonics.meaning: The radical car and the kanji car are exactly the same. Make sure you study your radicals... though don't do it while driving.
mnemonics.reading: When we need to remember the reading しゃ, we use "shaman". There's a car. It's the nicest car you've ever seen. Exquisite, beautiful. Wouldn't you be surprised to learn it belongs to a shaman (しゃ)? Well it does. This shaman charges a premium for his shaman services so he can afford fancy cars like this. The more fantastic you make this car, the better. Also, feel the surprise of a shaman getting out of this car. What a cool dude that shaman is.

mnemonics.meaning: If someone has a big head you have to try to focus on the center of it when you talk to them. You don't want to get caught with your eyes wandering all over their big head. Stare right at the center of their face. Ah geez, their eyes are kinda far away from here. You can really only see their nose...
mnemonics.reading: This is the center of the 王's (おう) head so you have to be extra careful not to look anywhere else. The 王 will definitely cut off your normal-sized head if he sees you looking all over his big head and not at the center.

mnemonics.meaning: The beggar is pointing his forehead up at you, his feet trapped in the ground. What diabolical scheme are you planning with this poor beggar you trapped? Turns out, you're planning to copy him to have your own version of him. You can imagine the whole story - him walking along, you setting a trap... and then whamo! You catch him. Then, come up with some crazy way / invention you're going to copy him. Are you cloning? Are you just taking his skin? Are you removing his forehead to grab his brain? Up to you - just make sure you make it ridiculous enough to remember.
mnemonics.reading: To remember the reading しゃ, we use the word "shaman". You finally decide on how you're going to copy him. You hire a shaman (しゃ) and have the shaman perform a sacred shaman cloning ritual. The shaman runs around for a bit, doing ridiculous things. Imagine it dancing about and mumbling shamanic chants as the beggar is copied.

mnemonics.meaning: The leader samurai didn't become leader by sitting around not taking action. He got to where he is by doing. Imagine the leader samurai doing things. He's doing more than anyone else, no one can keep up with what he's doing.
mnemonics.reading: He was doing things with sheep (し). He is the leader of the sheep clan, and he was able to do more with sheep than anyone else. That's why he's the leader. Picture the leader samurai doing lots of sheep things. He's shearing sheep. He's feeding sheep. He's doing everything you could possibly do, because he's the sheep samurai.

mnemonics.meaning: The ear radical and ear kanji are the same in looks as well as meaning. Study those radicals hard to make sure you know your kanji as well!
mnemonics.reading: Put your hand to your ear and sing... "Mimimimimimiiiii!" (みみ) and listen to your tone with your ear. This is sort of a stereotypical singer sort of image. Make sure you concentrate a lot when you're listening to your mimimimiiii tone. In fact, why don't you do it out loud right now - make a little fool of yourself. It's fun, and it'll help you to remember!

mnemonics.meaning: When the sun is over the cross it's time to go to church... which is so darn early. And if you want to get to church early, you need to be fast, otherwise you'll be too late. Imagine the sun coming up slowly, over the horizon. It then lines up with the cross, and at that moment, your alarm goes off, waking you up. You check the alarm clock, and instead of displaying the time, it just says EARLY and FAST on it, flashing in big red letters and alternating.
mnemonics.reading: To remember the そう reading we use the word "soul." When you're forced to get up fast and early you can feel it in your soul (そう). You're so tired and it's so early, your soul cries out, "Please don't make me go this fast this early. I'm gonna leave your body if you keep this up!" But you get your soul up early and head to the church fast anyway, because you're doing all of this for your soul in the first place!

mnemonics.meaning: You're looking for a treasure, but no normal treasure... a treasure that's a stash of energy. Not gold, money, or anything like that. Imagine yourself finding it, and opening up a treasure chest. Out bursts a spirit ball of energy like you've never seen. Try to touch the energy spirit, it's pretty amazing. Is it solid? Does it shock you? What does it feel like? Be sure to imagine it out.
mnemonics.reading: As you reach inside the energy spirit, you feel something hard inside. It's a large key (き) that gives you access to another treasure. You take the key and open another treasure that's nearby. Open it up and see what's inside. Imagine something spectacular.

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to dry your horns you need to lay them flat. If they aren't flat they'll always be a little damp somewhere and you'll never have a moment's peace. Imagine carefully taking off your horns and laying them flat on a paper towel. You have to smooth them out so they're as flat as possible.
mnemonics.reading: Being flat isn't enough, so you cover the whole thing in hay (へい). Hay absorbs water, so you add a flat layer of it. Imagine carefully laying a flat layer of hay on top of your flat horns. You feel really at peace and... you're tired now. You decided to lie on top of the hay and take a nap while you wait for your horns to dry.

mnemonics.meaning: A leader with a spoon is planting flowers so that one day this place may be full of beautiful flowers. It's kind of weird that the flowers radical is only a part of the flower kanji, but you'll make do. Just focus on the fact that the leader is planting all these flowers for a bigger picture thing (that's what leaders do). He wants there to be flowers for future generations as well, because he's a nice dude like that.
mnemonics.reading: The leader can't stop planting flowers though. He's going crazy. Maybe it's the pollen? He comes up to someone named Hannah (はな) and starts planting flowers in her face, probably killing her in the process. Do you know anyone named Hannah? Any famous people, perhaps? Try to come up with someone you know of named Hannah that you can imagine to be in this mnemonic, to help you remember it better.

mnemonics.meaning: The radical for foot and the kanji for foot are exactly the same. That being said, there's also another meaning you should keep in mind, which is sufficient. If you think about it, one foot should be sufficient enough to walk around with if you hop. Same kanjis and radicals make Jack a happy boy. You should also learn the other meaning as well, though, if you can.
mnemonics.reading: What do you wear on your foot? You wear a sock (そく). Just think about your bare feet. Think about them too much. Feel how cold it is on your feet. Now, put on a sock to make it feel better. Ahhh, so nice!

mnemonics.meaning: Take your fingers to the street to hit some people! Street fingers are for curling into a fist. And that street fist wants to do some hitting! Imagine: it's just you, your fingers, and the wild street. It's hitting time!
mnemonics.reading: As you hit one chump after another, suddenly your dad (だ) comes marching out of your house. Uh oh. Dad caught you hitting, which, honestly, isn't a very nice thing to do, so he has every right to stop you. Now imagine your dad saying, "Don't do a hit!" over and over at you. "I'm sorry dad! But the streets were calling me!"

mnemonics.meaning: There is a leaf growing out of the sun! You fly out into space to check it out and when you get closer you see that it isn't just one leaf, it's a hundred! That makes sense, you wouldn't be able to see just one leaf on the sun from where you were on earth. Imagine flying toward the sun to see a hundred leaves growing together in the shape of one big leaf. You want to go closer!
mnemonics.reading: You fly closer, counting all one hundred leaves when you hear a strange sound. You take off your space helmet and hear, "GUH HYUCK (ひゃく)!" You know that laugh... it's Goofy! On top of the hundredth leaf is Goofy laughing and waving around. He must have built this leaf tower to get your attention. Imagine hearing Goofy guh-hyuck over and over after you save him from being stranded on the sun. How would you feel being stuck in a cramped ship with laughing Goofy and his hundred leaves? Oh, you thought he would leave those behind? Nope, they saved him so you have to take them back too. Happy travels!

mnemonics.meaning: Add a drop of something magical to water and suddenly it turns into big block of ice, just like that. Imagine yourself adding that drop. What is it exactly? Something pretty potent, that's for sure. Now go ahead and touch the block of ice... wow, it's really cold — and only from one drop, too. Feel the burn on your finger from where you touched the ice.
mnemonics.reading: When you think of ice, I want you to think of someone frozen with ice. Do you know anyone named Corey (こおり)? Anyone famous named Corey, perhaps Corey Feldman? Imagine this Corey person frozen solid with ice. How did this happen? Was it your fault? Imagine the situation that would get Corey frozen like this.

mnemonics.meaning: The insect radical and insect are the same in looks as well as and meaning. It's times like these when you gotta hope you're studying your radicals!
mnemonics.reading: It's an insect! Get it! You squish it with your foot - what sound does it make? A mush (むし) sound. Imagine little words that say "mush" flying out from under your foot as you mush the poor thing. What does a "mush" sound sound like? You'll have to come up with something unique to yourself, and focus on it to remember this reading.

mnemonics.meaning: The roof child stands upon the roof, holding up a single letter, a single character, a single symbol for the world to see. More people can see this character since the kid is on the roof.
mnemonics.reading: The character that is being shown is "J," which stands for Jesus (じ). The kid wants everyone to see this letter and symbol. Imagine the child holding up the letter yelling at everyone who passes that the "J" stands for "Jesus." And yes, this kid just loves the Big Lebowski.

mnemonics.meaning: Rice paddy power comes from a man. One man, in fact. He's running on a big wheel next to the rice paddy and providing all of the power for the rice to grow and be harvested. Picture the power this man is generating! Now look at the next rice paddy and you'll see it's on a different power grid with a different man powering it.
mnemonics.reading: A man can power an entire rice paddy until dawn (だん). Once dawn comes they need a little break, so they nap. But once dawn is over, they're back at it again! Picture the man watching as the first light of dawn tints the color of the sky, turning it pink and orange. He stops working, lies down, and falls asleep.

mnemonics.meaning: The radical master and the kanji master have the same meanings! This kanji also means main because the master is the main person of a dojo or household or business.
mnemonics.reading: Do you remember back to the radical mnemonic, where the master is floating a water drop above his head? Imagine back to there. Once you do, the most amazing thing happens. The master sends the drop of water into a chute (しゅ) and it goes careening through an intricate series of them. Picture this master of water controlling the droplet as it flies around inside these chutes, like he's solving a difficult puzzle with it. Astounding!

mnemonics.meaning: What is the evening mouth? Imagine a mouth that’s up in the night sky. It’s just there, talking, and only comes out at night. It only appears in one area of the world (what area would you choose? Imagine yourself going to that place to see the “night mouth.”), and appears only one month out of the year (more on this in a second). The “evening mouth” is the most famous thing in the _____ area (this is the area you choose). He’s so famous that everybody knows his name (“Evening Mouth.”). Imagine yourself going to the area you chose, and watching “Evening Mouth” speak.
