That butcher is a such a sarcastic person.
「Ironic」という曲の中に、うまい皮肉はひとつも見当たらなかった。
Not one thing in the song "Ironic" is a proper example of irony.

mnemonics.meaning: When you enter a company you're actually joining a company. Welcome, new recruit. Prepare to be hazed!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: この会社には、四月に入社しました。
I joined this company in April.
トーフグの入社しけんはグーグルの入社しけんよりもむずかしい。
Tofugu's employment exam is more difficult than Google's.
大学を卒業したらすぐに、大きな金融機関に入社するか、アメリカ合衆国の大統領になれたらいいなと思っている。
As soon as I graduate from college, I hope to either join a big financial firm or be the president of the United States.

mnemonics.meaning: A large voice is probably pretty large. Maybe even annoying, too. That's why this is a large voice or a loud voice.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 声 is ごえ (rendaku'd version of the reading you know: こえ). The reading for 大 is the kun'yomi reading, like with the word 大きい (おおきい). Just imagine a loud voice saying "おお！."

sentences: そんな大声を出さないでください。
Please don’t use such a loud voice.
おもわず大声を出してわらってしまった。
I couldn't help laughing out loud.
クリスティーナは大声の持ち主で、残念なことにそれを使うのを全くはばからない。
Christina has a loud voice, and unfortunately, she’s not afraid to use it.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:  You have a ton of sunlight where you live. This creates heat. With this sunlight heat you're able to make your favorite food in the world: hickory (ひかり) smoked bacon. Mmm, taste that delicious bacon.

sentences: 太ようの光がまぶしいので、カーテンをしめてください。
The light from the sun is blinding, so please close the curtains.
月の光にてらされて、かなえちゃんの歯がまるでパールのように見えるよ。
In the moonlight, your teeth look just like pearls, Kanae.
北朝鮮で行方不明になったあなたの子供には、まだ微かに希望の光が残っている。
There is still a slight glimmer of hope left for your child who was lost in North Korea.

mnemonics.meaning: What happens when light travels a year? You have a light-year.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ちきゅうから月までは、一おく分の四光年です。
It is four one hundred millionths of a light-year from the earth to the moon.
ポートランドの中しんから北の方に四光年すすんだら、どこにつきますか。
If we go north from the center of Portland for four light-years, where will we be?
光年とは、光の速度で1年間進み続け到達出来る距離だ。貴様が俺と対決しようなんて、一万光年早いわ。
A light-year is the distance that light can travel over the course of one year. You are 10,000 light-years too early to be facing me.

mnemonics.meaning: If you study writing it's called literature. You'll get to study lots of things other people wrote before you!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 文学をよむいみとは何だろうか。
What’s the significance of reading literature?
わたしは大学で、イギリス文学をせんこうしていました。
I was majoring in English literature in university.
村上春樹の作品は、純文学のふりをした大衆文学だと思います。
I think Haruki Murakami's work is pop literature pretending to be pure literature.

mnemonics.meaning: The の particle makes it so the 人 belongs to the 男. Basically, this literally means "a man person" or "a person of man." It's a more polite way to say plain old man, though, so all you have to remember is that.
mnemonics.reading: This word is actually two separate words combined with a particle. So, since you treat them like separate words, you read each of them with the kun'yomi readings (they are both single kanji words all alone). That being said, in level 4 you learned about the vocab readings for these separate words, so use that knowledge to remember the reading for this word as well.

sentences: ああ！この男の人が、すず木さんですか。
Ah! Is that guy Suzuki?
あそこに立っている外人の男の人のとなりにいる女の人があのゆう名なまつい一代さんです。
The lady next to the foreign guy standing over there is THE famous Kazuyo Matsui.
背の高い男の人はTシャツを着ていて、背の低い男の人はセーターを着ています。
The tall guy is wearing a T-shirt and the short guy is wearing a sweater.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of many? It is also many (or you could say much). Speaking of which, there are so many kanji to learn, ammiright?
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Think of something that is many. Doesn't matter what it is as long as you imagine a ridiculous number of them. Many of them. So many that they start avalanching into you and crushing you. The last thing you yell is "おお!!!" as you get smushed.

sentences: このりょうりは多すぎます。
There is too much food.
「自分は正しい」とおもいこんでいる人は多い。
There are many people who firmly believe that they are right.
電車にはとても多くの乗客が乗っていたので、眠ることはできなかったが、大声で歌うことはできた。
I wasn’t able to sleep because there were far too many people on the train, so I just sang loudly instead.

mnemonics.meaning: You have many parts. Look at them all. You have to choose one of the parts. You can't decide which one you want. This one? Maybe. How about this one? Hmm, maybe that one too.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: かさは、多分外にあります。
Maybe the umbrella is outside.
多分、レイヤーさんなのかもしれないよ。
Perhaps, she is a cosplayer.
明日の夜は多分雪になるから、雪だるまを作ろう。
It’s probably going to snow tomorrow, so let’s make a snowman.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Luckily for you, this word uses the on'yomi reading that you learned even though it's a single kanji all on its own. So, you should know it already!

sentences: 水よう日は、肉がやすいです。
On Wednesday, meat is cheap.
牛肉とぶた肉ととり肉の中ではどれが一ばんすきですか。
Among beef, pork, and chicken, which meat do you like the best?
お肉は、二枚の食パンに挟まれる、もっとも重要な具材です。
Meat is the most important component between two slices of bread.

mnemonics.meaning: This is the noun version of the kanji meet. So it means meeting.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: きんようびの夜に、女子会をします。
I’m having a girls-only party on Friday night.
そのメンバーの会はとてもおも白そうですね。
The assembly with those members sounds very interesting.
この会、また開こうよ！
Let’s open this meeting again!

mnemonics.meaning: The お is an honorific that makes this word a bit more fancy. When you're talking about money you gotta be fancy, after all. So, you're basically saying "gold" in a nicer way. What was gold back in the day? It was money.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 金 is different from the one you learned with the kanji. Makes sense since this is a single kanji with hiragana attached. Here's a mnemonic to help you:  You've saved up a ton of money. With it you're going to buy something awesome. Then, suddenly someone hits you in the knees with a bat. Now you have to spend all your money buying a cane (かね). Sucks for you :(

sentences: この写しんは、お金よりも大切です。
This photo is more important than money.
お金をなめているとバチが当たるよ！
If you're careless with money, it's going to bite you in the butt.
この機械は、お金を取りあげるけどなんの見返りもくれないから、気をつけた方がいいよ。
You should be aware that this machine takes your money and gives you nothing in return.

mnemonics.meaning: The moon light (not sunlight!) can be bright sometimes. This is night when you're stumbling home from a nomikai after work. What is this light from the moon called? It's moon light. This word can also mean a moonbeam as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the on'yomi readings put together, though 月 is modified and shortened a bit. げつ goes to げっ. Make note of the different sized つ otherwise you'll be confused why you keep getting this one wrong over and over again!

sentences: そのよるは、月光がとてもきれいでした。
The moonlight was very beautiful that night.
一りんの白い花に、月光がさえざえとふりそそいでいた。
The bright moonlight was beaming down onto a white flower.
月光に照らされた彼女は、とても美しかった。
She looked so beautiful in the moonlight.

mnemonics.meaning: The next month is the next month! It isn't this month or the month before, it's the next one!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 来月たん生日会をするので、かなえさんも来てください。
I am having a birthday party next month, so please come too, Kanae.
花火大会の日は来月の何日でしたっけ？
What day next month is the day of the fireworks display?
今日海に落とした眼鏡を探すために、来月スキューバダイビングを始めることにしたよ。
Next month I’ll start scuba diving to find the glasses I lost at sea today.

mnemonics.meaning: The next year is next year! It isn't last year or this year, it's the next one!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 来年はアメリカにかえるつもりです。
I’m thinking of going back to America next year.
今年も来年もさ来年もわたしはニートをつづけるつもりです。
I plan to continue being a NEET this year, next year, and the year after that.
来年の今頃に来てくれよ。ハウストレーラー用のキャンプ場で、一番でかいトレーラーが俺のだよ。
Come at this time next year. I’ll have the biggest trailer in the trailer park.

mnemonics.meaning: This word is so simple. North + West = Northwest.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ひこうきは、北西にむかっています。
The airplane is heading northwest.
ポートランドから車で一じかん半ほど北西の方にいくと、シーサイドというまちにつきます。
If you drive about an hour and a half northwest from Portland, you will arrive at a city called Seaside.
ここから北西の方角のどこかに、パンストを落とした。
I lost my pantyhose somewhere northwest of here.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This implies that it is your older brother, by the way. Not somebody else's.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your older brother is different from everyone else's. He has odd powers... some would say powers of the force. Do you know what his name is? It's Ani (あに), short for Anikin... wait a sec, does that sound familiar?

sentences: 山下さんはわたしの兄ににていますね。
You look like my older brother, Mr. Yamashita.
一ヶ月まえに兄がくろラブをつれていえにかえってきました。
A month ago, my older brother came home with a black labrador.
兄は、とうふにコーヒーをかけてたべるのがすきだ。
My older brother likes eating tofu covered in coffee.

mnemonics.meaning: You have your self part. Part of your self is you. This is oneself. This is myself. Wait, who is this part of me? You're not sure... wait, no, it's myself. Is it? Be a little psychotic for a moment as you try to remember this vocab word.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ちゃんと自分でしゅくだいをしました。
I finished the homework perfectly all by myself.
自分に自しんがないとえらべない色だよね。
That's the color you can only choose if you are confident with yourself, isn't it?
もちろん私は自分と話しますよ。だって、時には専門家の意見が必要ですもの。
Of course I talk to myself. Sometimes I need expert advice.

mnemonics.meaning: One times is one time. How many times? Just one.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Take note that 一 is shortened (as it often is) to いっ.

sentences: もう一回、言ってください。
Please say it once more.
平日は一日に一回シャワーをあびますが、休日はぜんぜんあびません。
I take a shower once a day during the week, but not at all over the weekend.
もう一回欲しいのかい、ハニー？
Do you want it one more time, honey?

mnemonics.meaning: When a car has sky in it (and not, say, a bunch of people) it is free to give you a ride. If you see this sign lit up on a taxi feel free to hail it down, it will be able to take you somewhere. It is an open taxi.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: タクシーのひょうじが「空車」となっているときは、おきゃくさんはだれものっていません。
When a taxi is displaying "Open Taxi," there are no customers aboard.
この辺りのコインパーキングがいつも空車なのがふしぎでしょうがない。
I'm really curious why the parking lots around here are always empty.
空車のタクシーが全然通らない。
No empty taxis have passed us.

mnemonics.meaning: You want to talk about the origin where something comes from. That's where it is from originally.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: このサイトは本来かめのせいそくちとしてつかわれていた。
This site was originally used as a turtle habitat.
その言ばの本来のいみをしっていますか。
Do you know the original meaning of that word?
本来漢字は悪いものではない。
Kanji in and of itself isn’t a bad thing.

mnemonics.meaning: You have your body power. This is just another way to say physical strength. Watch out, if you use too much of your physical strength you may run out of physical stamina and endurance completely! They're tied together, so make sure to pace yourself.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: わたしは体力があまりありません。
I have practically no physical strength.
コウイチには、うで立てふせを八十回する体力はありません。
Koichi doesn't have stamina to do 80 push-ups.
その熱が彼の体力を弱めたが、まだ自分で水を飲む体力は残っていた。
The fever weakened his body, but he was still strong enough to drink water by himself.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji it uses the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, you learned this reading with the kanji.

sentences: 雨はまだふっていません。
It hasn’t rained yet.
一年中雨がふるくにの王子として生まれたことをくいています。
Unfortunately, I was born prince of a country that has rain all year long.
私は雨の臭いが好きで、あなたはそんな臭いがする。だからあなたのことが大好きなの。
I like the smell of rain and you smell like it. That’s why I love you.

mnemonics.meaning: What is real is right. It is the reality. It is also the truth. Don't believe anything that isn't real and true.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: それは本当ですか？
Is that true?
さいきんの大学生はスマホでレポートをかくってきいたけど、本当かなあ。
I heard that these days university students write essays on their smart phones, but I wonder if that's true.
本当に下手なのです。
I’m really awful at it.

mnemonics.meaning: The close years are years that aren't too long ago. They are the recent years.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 近年、日本しゅがまたブームになっています。
There has been another boom in Japanese alcohol in recent years.
近年のディズニーランドは、あまりこんざつしていないというのはかんぜんなるデマです。
It's a total lie that Disneyland hasn't been that packed in recent years.
豆腐を食べている河豚の存在が、近年徐々に明らかとなってきた。
The existence of a tofu-eating fugu has slowly been coming to light in recent years.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.  Note that this word refers to the grains of rice more than something that's a meal. If you're eating rice at a meal you'd call it ごはん. This is like when you're talking about the rice in the fields or rice grains or something like that.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:  "Everyone, we have rice! Come (こめ) and get it!"

sentences: 米をかうのをわすれてしまいました。
I forgot to buy rice.
１おく円のおもさはやく１０キロときいたので、１０キロのお米のふくろをだきしめながら、１おく円をもっているところをそうぞうしてみた。
I heard that the weight of 100 million yen is about 10kg, so I tried to imagine what it would be like to hold 100 million yen while holding a bag of 10kg rice.
私の一番好きな朝ごはんは、生米と味噌汁です。
My favorite breakfast consists of uncooked rice and miso soup.

mnemonics.meaning: This word is the kanji same with hiragana attached, and it also means same. It's a bit of an oddball among Japanese adjectives, because you don't need な or い to attach it to a noun. So it's usually considered to be a "special" な-adjective. Have a look at the context sentences to see it in action!
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  When you think of the word "same" think same owner (おな). You're looking at a restaurant that has a sign that says, "New owners!" However, when you walk in you see it's the same terrible owner you remember from before. What a liar.

sentences: 毎日、同じ人に会います。
I meet the same person every day.
今回のしけんは、ぜん回とほぼ同じ内ようでした。
This exam was almost the same questions as last time.
あの店と同じ味のラーメンがどうしても作りたいんだ。
I want to make ramen that tastes the same as that shop’s no matter what.

mnemonics.meaning: You have the same day, which comes out to same day.
mnemonics.reading: The readings follow the regular jukugo rules (on'yomi reading) but take note that 日 is read as じつ, the alternate on'yomi reading. You've been seeing this reading a lot lately, so hopefully you know it by now and it's easy!

sentences: それらは、同日にはつばいされました。
Those were launched on the same day.
すきなバンドのライブがちがうはこで同日にかぶっていて、どれにいこうかちょうぜつまよっています。
The bands I like have concerts in different music clubs on the same day and I'm really not sure which one I should go to.
父の死と同日に、アポロ11号が月面着陸に成功した。
On the same day of my father’s death, Apollo 11 succeeded in landing on the moon’s surface.

mnemonics.meaning: You enter into a study (place). When does this happen? It happens when you get accepted into a school, aka school admission, university admission, or entry into school.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: これは、入学のおいわいのプレゼントです。
Here is a congratulatory present for getting into school.
父が入学金をはらうのをわすれてしまったんです。
My father forgot to pay the enrollment fee.
トムはオックスフォード大学に入学できたと思っていたんだけど、どうもその合格証明書はトムの両親がエイプリルフールのジョークとして作ったものだったようだぜ。
Tom thought he got into Oxford, but apparently the acceptance letter was an April Fool’s joke his parents made.

mnemonics.meaning: Your study year is kind of like the years you've studied. Where do you study? School. What is a year of study in a school? It's your school grade.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: かれは、兄と同じ学年です。
He is in the same year as my older brother.
トーフグには、小学こうてい学年のファンもいれば、１００才をこえるファンもいる。
Tofugu not only has fans in early elementary school, but also elderly fans over 100 years old.
あの給食の後、三年生の学年の三分の一が吐いた。
One third of the third grade threw up after school lunch.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: As a human (we think), you have a lot of skin. But sometimes a normal shower isn't enough to wash all that skin. What do you do when you can't fit all your skin in the shower or the tub? You get your skin cleaned at the car wash, of course!

sentences: にわに、みかんの皮がおちていました。
There were orange peels laying in the garden.
らく天で、天ねんの牛の皮でできた小さいラグをかった。
I bought a small natural cowhide rug on Rakuten.
俺のジャケットは、100%竜の皮でできているんだ。
My jacket is made of 100% dragon skin.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:  In the sky, you are the ruler. You are known as "The soarer!" (そら). Imagine your theme song and make sure it includes "soarer of the sky" or something awesome like that.

sentences: 空にきれいなにじがかかっている。
There is a beautiful rainbow in the sky.
女心とあきの空といいますが、男心だってかわりやすいんですよ。
They say that women's minds and the autumn skies change quickly, but men's minds change quickly too.
今夜映画E.T.の有名なシーンがちゃんと見れるくらい、空が晴れ渡っているといいんだが。
I hope the sky tonight is clear enough for us to see the famous scene from the movie E.T.

mnemonics.meaning: You'd think that water color would have something to do with watercolors, but it doesn't. No, it has to do with the color of water, which, ironically, is sky blue in English. Light blue works as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word consists of the kun'yomi reading of 水 and the kun'yomi reading of 色. For 水 you'll know this reading via your vocab studies. For 色 it just so happens to be the reading you learned with the kanji.

sentences: あの水色のバッグがほしいんですが。
I want that light blue bag.
トーフグのTシャツは、さわやかな水色です。
Tofugu T-shirt is breezy sky blue.
どうして今日の空は水色なんだろう？
Why is the sky light blue today?

mnemonics.meaning: The near day is a day coming very soon. It's a day coming in a few days or in the coming days. In other words, you wouldn't use this word for something that's going to happen in a few minutes, or a few months.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are both on'yomi readings that you've learned. Just take note that 日 is the alternate reading じつ.

sentences: このゲームは、近日はつばいよていです。
This game is scheduled to be released soon.
田中さんがたのしみにしていたえいがが、ついに近日こうかいします。
The movie Mr. Tanaka was looking forward to will finally be released in a few days.
近日中にお会いして、ネットで見たことを一緒に語り合いましょう。
Let’s hang out in person soon and talk about things we saw online.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:  Did you hear that sound? It's barely audible (おと). Go ahead and say the word "audible" with the pronunciation of おと to help you to remember this.

sentences: 二かいから、大きな音がしました。
There was a loud noise upstairs.
となりのいえから、すごく上手なリコーダーの音が聞こえてきます。
I can hear the sounds of a very good recorder coming from next door.
金魚が泣いている音を聞いたことはある？
Have you ever heard the sound that a goldfish makes when it cries?

mnemonics.meaning: What shape has four angles? The most common one is a square, but it could also be a rectangle or even a cube.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings for the kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this word!

sentences: じゃがいもを、四角に切ってください。
Cut the potatoes into cubes, please.
ツイッターのアイコンの形を今の丸から四角にもどしてほしい。
I want the twitter icon to go back from the current round shape to the square one.
どうしてほとんどの窓は真四角か長四角なんだろう。イタリア型の窓とかも作ったらいいのに。
Why are most windows either squares or rectangles? They should start making windows shaped like Italy.

mnemonics.meaning: Who has a study life? Only one person that I know of, and that's a student.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 学生は今日、うちでどこをべんきょうしますか。
Which parts will students study at home today?
学生わり引ってありますか？
Do you have student discount?
「我々はみな人生の学生だ。」と言いながら、父はおならをした。
"We are all students of life," my dad said while farting.

mnemonics.meaning: You have sun light. What kind of light would this be? Obviously sunlight.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this one uses the on'yomi readings, though にち gets shortened to にっ, so take note of that. Otherwise, you should be able to read this one!

sentences: 日光をあびすぎるのは体によくない。
Bathing too long in the sunlight isn’t good for your body.
できるだけちょくしゃ日光にさらされないよう気をつけています。
I'm being as careful as possible to not get exposed to direct sunlight.
何故か日光を見るといつもくしゃみが出ます。
Seeing sunlight always makes me sneeze for some reason.

mnemonics.meaning: You have some gold balls. What balls are more important than any other balls, at least for a dude? That would be his testicles.  This word came about because tanuki scrotum skin would be used to pound down gold into sheets. Tanuki scrotums are apparently very good at this because they are very strong and very flexible. Strange, yeah? That's why Gold balls = testicles.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the on'yomi for 金 and the kun'yomi for 玉. If you know the readings of your kanji, you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 金玉がヒリヒリするんです。
My testicles sting.
おれの金玉はぜったい他の男のばいはたらいてるとおもうぜ。
I'm sure that my testicles are working twice as hard as the other mens'.
金玉を金色にする手術は、六ヶ月先まで予約がいっぱいです。
The surgery to make testicles gold in color is fully booked for the next six months.

mnemonics.meaning: その means "that" or "the", and その plus other means things like the others, other, and other than that, depending on the context.
mnemonics.reading: This has two readings, but luckily you learned one of them when you learned the kanji, and the other one when you learned the word 他. The two readings are usually interchangeable, too.

sentences: その他色々あります。
There are many others.
その他、何か言いたいことはありますか？
Other than that, is there anything you'd like to say?
その他のゴミはどうすればいいですか。
What should I do with the other garbage?

mnemonics.meaning: The now times is this time.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 今回は、やめておきます。
I decided to pass this time.
今回のマラソン大会では一いでした。
I was the first place winner at this marathon.
前回お前が運転した時は、岸にぶつかりそうになったじゃん。だから今回は俺が釣り船を運転するよ。
I’ll drive the fishing boat this time because last time you drove it, we almost ran into the shore.

mnemonics.meaning: What thousand? Could be five thousand, two thousand, or ten thousand, since you're asking. Let's generalize. How do you say all of those amounts at the same time? You say "thousands."
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just take note that 千 is read as ぜん and not せん because of rendaku.

sentences: 何千回も、れんしゅうしました。
I’ve practiced thousands of times.
とつぜん、何千ものベーコンがそらからふってきた。
Suddenly, thousands of bacon strips dropped from sky.
巨人攻撃の被害者は、何千人にものぼった。
Victims of the titan attack numbered in the thousands.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the on'yomi reading which you learned with the kanji. This is probably because this word gets attached to numbers usually, which makes it behave more like jukugo. So, you can have １回, ２回, ３回, or even １００回 if you're into that sort of thing.

sentences: 日本に一回行ったことがあります。
I’ve been to Japan once.
アメリカから日本までおよいでわたるけいかくを立てたが、もう八回ほどと中で中止になっている。
I've made plans to swim from America to Japan, but they've been put on hold eight different times now.
何回砂を食べたか自分でも数えきれないよ。
I can’t count the number of times I’ve eaten sand.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji 外 means outside, but this word means to be disconnected, to come off, or to be off. It's used when something separates from or comes off of something else. It's intransitive, meaning that it happens on its own. You don't do it, but it just disconnects itself. You already learned 外す, which is used when YOU disconnect something. Like many transitive verbs, that one ends in す. 外れる, on the other hand, means that something disconnects all on its own. To help you remember the difference, imagine yourself walking up a flight of stairs and the rail (れる) coming off in your hand. Oops! You didn't do that, it happened all by itself.
mnemonics.reading: That rail has はず to be fixed, otherwise it's going to come off again, someone's going to get hurt.

sentences: あみ戸が外れてしまいました。
The sliding door came off.
けがをして、スタメンから外れることになっちゃったんだ。
I got injured, so I'm going to be taken off the starting players.
プラグが外れたので、Mr.ロボットはありがとうといえなくなった。
Since the plug was disconnected, Mr. Robot was no longer able to say, "thank you," anymore.

mnemonics.meaning: You know this is a verb because it ends with an う sound. The kanji for this word is right or success, so what's the verb form of that? Turns out it's a ton of things. Like, a crazy amount of things. I tried narrowing it down for you, but it will still be a lot. This word tends to be about getting an answer right. As in, to be right or to be on target. It means many other things too, but I think these are the two meanings you'll see the most, so focus on those.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember the あ portion.  You need to guess the correct answer. What do you choose? You guess A (あ) and hope it's right. Turns out you were right on the money. Well done! Imagine yourself winning a fabulous prize.

sentences: 自分の予想が当たって、嬉しいです。
I’m glad my guess was right.
人に石が当たったらどうするんだ。
If a person was hit with a stone, what would you do?
まんいんでん車で、手がとなりの女のしりに当たってしまい、ちかんにまちがえられたらどうしようと不あんでいっぱいになった。
In a packed train, my hand accidentally touched the butt of the woman next to me and I was so worried I’d be mistaken for a molester.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means see, and 見える is to be visible, or to be in sight, though it's often more naturally translated into English as can see. It's used when you don't actively intend to see something, it just happens. This verb can also mean to seem, when talking about how you perceive something you can see.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji (the kun'yomi reading). So as long as you know that you should be able to read this word as well.

sentences: ここから火山が見える。
The volcano is visible from here.
あそこの赤いはたが見えますか。
Can you see the red flag over there?
自分が人からどう見えるのかがすごく気になる。
I'm really curious about how I seem to others.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means come so you know this word means to come.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is pretty strange. It changes depending on the type of verb form you use (it's a pesky exception verb). To remember the reading of this word, here's a mnemonic:  "I want you to come to the cool (く) side, Luke," says Darth Vader. "What?" replies Luke. Just replace this line into the famous line from Star Wars. Say it out loud. Do the Vader voice. It'll help you to remember.

sentences: アメリカから来ました。
I came from America.
来る、きっと来る。
She will come. I'm sure she will come.
二度と戻って来るんじゃねーぞ！
Never come back!

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. The kanji means below so this means something gets lower, by falling or dropping. For example: Prices get lower or fall. Squirrels come down from trees. See? No direct object here. That's why this verb means to get lower or to fall.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Let's use a mnemonic to remember the reading of the kanji: You know it means to fall so instead of using a saw (さ) to cut down the tree, you decide to let it come to you. It has to come down all by itself. Picture yourself placing a saw at the foot of a tree then sitting back and waiting for it to drop itself at your knees. (This could actually work, don't you judge my methods!)

sentences: せかいじゅうのかぶかが下がった。
Stock prices all over the world fell.
ねつが三十七どに下がりました。
My temperature dropped to 37℃.
ズボンが下がるようにベルトをゆるめなさい。
Unfasten your belt so that your pants will hang down.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "life" so what is the verb form of that? Would it be "to do life"? No, probably not. In this case it is to give birth, or to produce. You'll have to differentiate this one from the word 生まれる as well. You can remember that this one means "to give birth" because when you compare, the act of giving birth probably feels shorter than the act of being birthed, at least in terms of sheer terror. The pain of giving birth will make it feel quick, when you look back on it... but just imagine how traumatized the baby must be from going through that as well. So, the act of giving birth is shorter, just like the word itself!
mnemonics.reading: You have to remember the う part of this word to be able to read it. It's the same as 生まれる, so that could help if you've learned that word already. If not, just imagine yourself giving birth, and all you can do is scream: "UUuUUuuUUuUuu!" (う).

sentences: かれのはつげんは、ぎもんを生んだ。
His remark produced problems.
ごかいを生むようなとうこうはしないでください。
Please do not post things that could give rise to misunderstandings.
おっとの子ではなかったが、生むしかなかった。
Even though it wasn’t my husband’s, I had no choice but to give birth to the baby.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means go so the verb form of this is to go.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You have to remember the い portion. To remember い we use the word "eagle."  You want to go somewhere (anywhere!) but you can't. An eagle (い) blocks your path. You try to go forward and it opens its wings and bites at you. You try to go back and it jumps at you. There's nowhere for you to go with this eagle standing there.

sentences: 今から、かいものに行きます。
I'm about to go shopping.
ようじができて、行けなくなってしまいました。
Something came up, so I'm not able to make it.
タコベルが無いので火星には行きたくない。
I wouldn’t want to go to Mars because they don’t have Taco Bell there.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. The kanji means above so this means something rises. For example: A fever goes up. The sun rises. See? No direct object here. That's why this verb means to rise or to go up. Be careful not to confuse this with its transitive buddy 上げる, which means "to lift something" or "to raise something." With that other verb, someone is doing the lifting, it's not happening by itself like it is here.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you can guess that it uses the kun'yomi reading, which also happens to be a reading you didn't learn when you learned the kanji. Let's use a mnemonic for the kun'yomi reading now, though. You have to remember at least the あ part to read it. You know that this word means to go up. Imagine something just rising on its own, like a floating tree or something. What would you say? Probably a "surprised" sound. Maybe you'd scream "あ!" when you saw this floating tree. If you need help remembering the hiragana part, imagine that it's a girl rising up and you scream "Ah! Girl!"(あがる).

sentences: どんどんねつが上がっています。
My fever is rising steadily.
三かいまでエレベーターで上がりましょう。
Let's go up to the 3rd floor using the elevator.
けむりが上がってる。
Smoke is rising.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji 入 means "enter," but this word does not mean "to enter" (which you already learned as 入る). Still, the meaning of 入れる is still related to the kanji's meaning: it means to insert or to put in. It's something you do to another object, like inserting a key into a lock, or your hand into a glove.
mnemonics.reading: When a vocab is a single kanji plus some okurigana (hiragana stuck on the end of kanji) it's almost always going to be the kun'yomi reading. This is one of two kun'yomi readings you'll be learning for the kanji 入. As long as you know that this vocab means to insert, you can use that to remember the reading as well.  Imagine inserting your hand into a hole and an eagle (い) flies out, screaming: "い!" This is something that happens every time you insert your hand into something: an eagle comes out. You don't know why.

sentences: しかくになにを入れますか。
What will you put in the square?
ここにおりがみを十二まい入れてください。
Please insert twelve pieces of origami paper here.
わたしはハンバーガーをひつぎに入れた。
I put a hamburger into the coffin.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means study or learning. When you do these things, what ends up happening? You learn. That's why this word means to learn.  There is another word that means "to learn" that is going to be more common, which is 習う. You'll learn this one later on. 学ぶ sounds a little more serious compared to 習う, so keep that in mind when you use it.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You have to remember the まな part to learn this word's reading. Think about a class you're taking. It's a manners class, and you're there to learn manners (まな). Imagine this study of manners and imagine yourself practicing it.

sentences: わたしは、どく学で日本ごを学んでいます。
I’m learning Japanese through self-study.
日本ごをべんきょうするのはやめて、トーフグといっしょにへんがおとへんなポーズを学びませんか？
Why don't you learn how to make weird faces and poses with Tofugu, instead of studying Japanese?
学ぶことは大切だけど、おそらくもっと大切なのはどのように学ぶかということじゃないだろうか。
Learning is important, but perhaps what’s more important is how you learn.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means make. The verb form of that is to make.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You have to remember the つく portion. In order to do that let's think about something that you're going to make. Imagine something really awesome. You complete it and look at your masterpiece. It's amazing. You realize right then and there that it's too cool (つく) for the general public to see. You proceed to smash it. It's way too cool.

sentences: 今日は、ばんごはんにやきそばを作ります。
Today, I will make yakisoba for supper.
フェイスブックのアカウントをふくすう作る方ほうをおしえてください。
Can you teach me how to create multiple Facebook accounts, please?
テスラ・コイルをどうやって作るのかを知っていたら良かったんだけどな。
I wish I knew how to make a Tesla coil.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means meet so the verb form of that is to meet or to encounter.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You have to remember the あ part but let's include the う as well for this one. Who do you want to meet more than anyone? Think about it. Then, imagine meeting them. The first thing they do is grab your arm and pinch it. You yell out "OW!" (あう) and they laugh and run away.

sentences: 日よう日に会う。
We’re meeting on Sunday.
ポートランドくうこうでばったりコウイチに会いました。
I ran into Koichi at the Portland airport.
明日の午後、大好きな俳優に会えるんです！
I get to meet my favorite actor tomorrow afternoon.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means mix so the verb version is to mix something.  There are similar words to this one, including 交じる which means "to be mixed" and 交わる which means "to intersect." This one is when you're doing the mixing. It's transitive. Like 交じる, the connotation is that the things being mixed are distinguishable from each other, like two types of fish, or books being mixed together. They don't become homogenous like paint or something would.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You have to remember the ま portion. Who would mix things for you (like cakes and other goodies) growing up? That would be your Ma (ま).

sentences: トランプをよく交ぜてください。
Mix the cards up well, please.
どうしてたくさんの男たちの中に女を一人交ぜたんだ？
Why did you mix one woman into group with a bunch of men?
豆腐と河豚を交ぜるのは危険です。
It’s dangerous to mix tofu and puffer fish.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means times. There's no good verb for the word "times" but you can probably imagine something doing something over and over and over again. What word would represent this? It would be to revolve, to go around, or to rotate. Bear in mind that this verb is intransitive, so it happens on its own. Something revolves or rotates, all by itself.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You have a bag of walnuts that you're bringing to a friend's house but you trip and drop them all on the ground. You shout, "Mah Walnuts! (まわ)" as they start to revolve around you on the ground. Picture your walnuts going around you, getting all dirty.

sentences: 今日は、おきゃくさんと１８ホールを回りました。
I went around 18 holes with a customer today.
百円玉はまだつくえの上で回っています。
That 100 yen coin is still spinning on the desk.
惑星が太陽の周りを回るように、その子猫たちが親猫の周りを回っている。
Those kittens revolve around their mother like the planets revolve around the sun.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means run so now you know the verb version of that is to run.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You have to remember the はし portion. Think of yourself running. It's nice. As you run, though, you notice the ground changing into something weird and mushy. Everything is turning into hash (はし) browns. You start to get sucked in, and soon you can't run anymore. Smell the hash browns and taste them too. What a terrible run this was.

sentences: えいがにおくれそうだったので、走りました。
I ran because I was almost late for the movie.
コウイチはカメよりもはやく走れる。
Koichi can run faster than a turtle.
人生走り続けるより、侍に首をはねられる方がずっとましだという結論に達しました。
I’ve come to the conclusion that having my head cut off by a samurai would be much better than running for my life.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means say, so the verb version of that is to say.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  To remember the reading い we use the word "eagle."  You're trying to say something, but every time you try to say anything an eagle (い) swoops down and pecks at your face then flies away. Just imagine yourself saying tiny bits of words, then an eagle crashing down on your face. Then, you wait in silence. Nothing happens. You try to say something again, and the eagle swoops down on you again.

sentences: ゆっくり言ってください。
Please say it slowly.
いつもありがとうってえいごで何て言うの？
How can I say, "Thank you always," in English?
ジェイクに、足を踏んでごめんって言うつもりなの？
Are you going to say sorry to Jake for stepping on his foot?

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う (in this case る) sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means separate (at least, that's one of its several meanings). So, the verb form of that is to separate something, to divide something,  to share something or  to split something.  You'll have to differentiate this word with 分かる which is very similar but has a totally different meaning. You'll need to learn the reading to do this, but think of it this way: You must "separate" your Wake (わけ) time from your sleeping time.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You are to separate a couple of children that really have fun together. When you separate them, they begin to cry and scream: WAAAAAAAAAHHHH (わ). Poor kids.

sentences: このにくまんを二人で分けましょう。
Let’s split this meat bun between two people.
生しを分けるけつだんになった。
It was a decision that spelt the difference between life and death.
ピザを半分に分けるなら、大きい方を下さい。
If you split the pizza, could you give me the bigger half?

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "stand" and this means to stand something up. It also can mean to make something, both in a physical sense, like making a sound, and a mental sense, like making a plan.  Don't confuse this with 立つ. 立てる means that you're standing something up. As in, "I stood up the action figure" or "I will erect the flag." You're doing the action to something else.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You have to remember the た portion. In order to do that, think of yourself standing up a huge sign. On it, written in big words: "ta ta (た)!"

sentences: ロウソクは、なん本立てますか？
How many candles will you put out?
このしゃしん立てを立てるためのスタンドをさがしています。
I’m looking for an easel to stand this photo frame up on.
ぼくのつくえにえんぴつを立ててくれませんか？
Could you please stand some pencils up on my desk?

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. Something comes to a stop. No direct object here. That's why this verb means to stop.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You come to a stop sign and decide to stop because the sign has a picture of a toe (と) on it. This toe looks eerily like a toe your Ma (ま) has too... and your Ma always taught you to stop and look both ways before crossing her toes.

sentences: あかしんごうで、くるまは止まりました。
The car stopped at the red signal.
心ぞうが止まるかとおもった。
I was so surprised I thought my heart leapt into my mouth.
こおりの上で、止まることができなかった。
I couldn’t stop on the ice.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "exit" and this is kind of a verb form of this. The word means to take out or to hand out, so it's like you're doing the action of causing something else to exit (rather than exiting yourself). You can remember this because the hiragana す is like the word "sue." Imagine yourself grabbing her and removing her from a box. スーを出す.
mnemonics.reading: The part of the word that you have to learn how to read is the だ portion. So, you already removed Sue from the box. Who else is in there that you have to remove? It's your Dad (だ) as well. Go ahead and remove him from the box as well.

sentences: つくえの上に、じしょを出してください。
Please put the dictionary out on the desk.
そのアメリカ人は、あしから二ひきのガラガラヘビにかまれたどくをぜんぶ出した。
That American removed all the venom he got from two rattle snakes out of his leg.
どろぼうはぬすんだものをすべて出してくばった。
The thief handed out all the goods he stole.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means think, so the verb version is to think about or to consider.  Note that this isn't the "to think" that is like "I think that he is a power ranger." No, this is more like the actual thinking action. That's why this word is "to think about" or "to consider" rather than plain old "to think" which is 思う.
mnemonics.reading: If you want to think, the best way to do so is to do the conga (かんが). Imagine yourself doing the conga and thinking away. You're so inspired! The thoughts are flowing as freely as your sweet, slow dance moves.

sentences: 少し考えさせてください。
Please let me think about it a little.
考えるな！かんじろ！
Don't think. Just feel!
私の娘は、もしタイタニック号が沈まなければ、みんなその代わりにディズニーランドに行くことができて、もっといい映画になったのにと考える。
My daughter thinks that the movie Titanic would have been better if the ship never sank and everyone went to Disneyland instead.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a weird word. Call it exceptional. You'll see this at train stations, especially. You know the kanji means go. So, something is going somewhere. Now just use the き to help you to remember that this word means train direction (aka it tells you which direction a train is going), because this word is the key (き) to you knowing what direction you're going in so you don't get lost. You could also remember this word as "bound for" aka "Bound for Tokyo Station."
mnemonics.reading: The reading is also an exception. It can be いき, but instead we're focusing on the ゆき reading. You have to remember the ゆ portion, so think of it this way:  Just think about the train direction that you (ゆ) need to go in. It's all about you. Not your friends or anyone else. You. You are the most important person at this train station.

sentences: しん大さか行きのしんかんせんのきっぷをください。
One shinkansen ticket for Shin-Osaka, please.
行きもかえりもあるくつもりです。
I'm thinking of walking both ways.
この電車は、トーフグオフィス行きです。
This train is bound for Tofugu Office Station.

mnemonics.meaning: A vehicle that run-goes is running and it's moving you somewhere else. You're traveling! We usually use this word to describe moving or running vehicles like cars and trains. Keep an eye on those context sentences to make sure you're using it right. ;)
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: あなたの車の走行マイルをおしえてください。
Can you tell me the mileage of your car?
バスの走行中にせきを立つのはきけんです。
Leaving your seat while the bus is moving is dangerous.
その電車は、ストライキが終わり次第、ホグワーツ魔法魔術学校への走行を再開する。
The train will start running to Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry again as soon as the strike is over.

mnemonics.meaning: When you have something with three angles, what shape is that? It's a triangle.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 三角のクラッカーをかってきてください。
Please go buy triangle crackers.
今、三角かんけいになっちゃってるんだよね。
I am stuck in a love triangle now.
カナダ人はピカソにかなり刺激を受けたに違いない。四角い箱に、丸いピザ、三角のピザスライスがあちこちにある。
Canadians must have been inspired by Picasso quite a bit. Square boxes, round pizzas, and triangle pizza slices are everywhere.

mnemonics.meaning: What's the big study? If I had to choose, I'd probably say this is college or university.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: わたしの大学には、中ごく人がたくさんいます。
There are a lot of Chinese people in my university.
アメリカの大学と日本の大学の主なちがいはなんですか。
What are the main differences between American universities and Japanese universities?
大学で解剖学を勉強したが、教科書は一度も開かなかった。
I studied anatomy in college, but I never opened a textbook.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 今 means now. What you probably don't know is that まで means "until." So, this word means until now.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is the kun'yomi reading which you learned previously when you learned the vocab word 今. You can tell this is a kun'yomi reading because it has hiragana attached. So if you know that, you should be able to read this word as well.

sentences: 今まで何をしていたんですか。
What have you been doing until now?
コウイチが今まで付きあったかの女は百万人に上るが、ようやく一人の女の人におちつきつつある。
Koichi had a million girlfriends up until now, but he is finally about to settle down with one woman.
お前が今までの中では一番の彼女だよ。
You are the best girlfriend I’ve had so far.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. This happens to be the reading you learned with the kanji, too, so don't feel like you're stuck in a valley of despair or anything. Rejoice!

sentences: あそこの谷で、くまを見ました。
I saw a bear in that valley.
はこねには大わく谷というむかし「じごく谷」といわれた谷があって、かんこうの名しょになっています。
In Hakone, there is a valley called Owakudani, which used to be called "Death Valley" a long time ago, and it is a famous tourist spot nowadays.
死の谷で自殺した男は、ダース・ベイダーのコスプレをしていた。
The guy who committed suicide in Death Valley was dressed as Darth Vader.

mnemonics.meaning: This is the kanji color repeated twice (the 々 character just repeats the kanji before it). When you have colors and colors and colors, you have a lot of variety. That's why this word means various.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this kanji is just the kun'yomi reading twice. Since you've learned the kun'yomi reading already, you should be able to read this word as well. Nothing tricky about it.

sentences: 色々な小せつをよみました。
I’ve read various types of novels.
色々考えたけっか、日よう日にたこやきパーティーをすることにしました。
After thinking about various things, I've decided to hold a takoyaki party on Sunday.
私のベッドの下に住んでいるトロールには色々な種類がいます。
There are various species of trolls that live under my bed.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji making it easy to remember!

sentences: はし本さんの声は、とてもひくいです。
Hashimoto’s voice is very low.
友人の声とその子どもの声がそっくりだ。
My friend's voice and her kid's voice are very alike.
あんたの声、ひどいな！
Your voice sounds awful!

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:  You go off to the west. It's the Wild West, even. There aren't many people out here, making it easy to find a niche (にし) for your snake oil business.

sentences: びょういんの西のたてものがわたしのアパートです。
The building on the west side of the hospital is my apartment.
ダリンは、西にむかっています。
Darin is heading west.
その頃、西ポートランドでは、鰐蟹がその道を渡っていた。
Meanwhile in West Portland, the Crabigator was crossing the road.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. What? Yeah, that's what.

sentences: 何と言いますか。
What would you say?
あなた、何さまのつもりですか。
Who do you think you are?
僕達がタイのホテルで飲んだ飲み物の名前は何？
What was the name of that drink we had at the hotel in Thailand?

mnemonics.meaning: You have what month - as in: what month is it? It's １０月, you fool. Get a job, hippy.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji. 何 is technically the kun'yomi, but it feels pretty on'yomi-ish if you ask me. The 月 uses the on'yomi, though.

sentences: 学こうは何月にはじまりますか。
What month do you start school?
それって何年何月何日何びょう、ちきゅうが何回回ったとき？
When did it happen? What year, what month, what day, what time, what second was it? How many times did Earth spin when it happened?
田中さんは何月生まれですか？
What month were you born in, Ms. Tanaka?

mnemonics.meaning: You have the kanji what and year, as in: "what year is it?"  This also means how many years too, depending on the context. As in: "How many years did you play soccer?"
mnemonics.reading: The readings are both the readings you learned with the separate kanji, meaning you should know them. How many years have you been studying kanji now? You should be able to read this one.

sentences: 何年生まれですか。
What year were you born?
おたくのお子さんは、何年に大学に入りましたか。
What year did your kid enter college?
アメリカの南北戦争は、何年間続いたんですか？
How many years did the American Civil War last?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji that uses the kun'yomi reading which is the reading you learned with the kanji.

sentences: わたしは、麦アレルギーがあります。
I have a wheat allergy.
大麦と小麦のちがいは何ですか。
What's the difference between barley and wheat?
「スクワット、スクワット、スクワット、麦とスクワット♪」屈伸をしながら彼は歌った。
"Squats, squats, squats, squats, oats and squats," he sang while squatting.

mnemonics.meaning: One life is all you get. It's your whole life. This can also mean all through life, and when it's used as an adjective it means lifelong.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 生 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who has been in charge of you your whole life? The shogun (しょう). He owns everyone and that's how it will stay for your entire life.

sentences: このゆびわは、一生、大切にします。
I will treasure this ring my entire life.
わたしの父は、しぬまで一生どくしんでした。
My father remained single all his life.
一生かけて償います。
I’ll make up for it with my life.

mnemonics.meaning: When you're doing something inside the company you're doing it within the company or in-house. For example, we do our kanji in-house. It gives it that artisan flavor.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: つぎの日よう日に、社内のバスケットボール大会があります。
Next Sunday there will be an in-house basketball tournament.
花さんは、社内けっこんをしてたいしょくしました。
Hana left the company after she married a man who worked in the same company.
最近、社内で変なことが流行っている。従業員が、会社の冷蔵庫の中の食べ物に名前をつけるのだ。今日は、俺は、「鈴木」と名付けられたオニギリを食べた。
Recently, there is a strange new trend in our company. Workers put names on food in the company fridge. Today, I had a rice ball named "Suzuki."

mnemonics.meaning: When you have fur string (aka string made of fur) what do you think of? Hopefully wool yarn.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for these kanji are the kun'yomi readings. With 毛 you should have learned this reading via the vocab word in the previous level. With 糸 it's actually the main reading for the kanji, so you should already know it.

sentences: みどり色の毛糸はありますか。
Do you have green yarn?
今日はとてもさむいので、友人があんでくれた毛糸のセーターをきています。
It is very cold today, so I am wearing the wool sweater that my friend knitted for me.
「毛糸の玉をほどいてください。お願いします。お願いします。」と、その幽霊は何度も私に頼んできた。
"Unwind a ball of yarn please. Please. Please!" the ghost asked me over and over again.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:  You look at your younger brother. He's a scheming one. He's smiling up at you. Why? Because he's lit a firecracker on your foot. It explodes, sending your toe flying. You yell "OH. Toe? TOE!" (おとうと) as you realize what's going on.

sentences: わたしの弟は、テレビを見ない。
My little brother doesn’t watch TV.
その青いかみの青年はぼくの弟です。
That young man with blue hair is my younger brother.
弟がビリヤードのボールを頭に投げつけてきたので、昨夜僕は病院に行くはめになった。
I ended up going to the hospital last night because my younger brother threw a pool ball at my head.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone who is blue in their years. This makes sense when you know that Asian babies are often born with blue butts, which you can associate with being young. So, Blue = Young (not only in this word, but in others as well). Someone who is blue in their years is a youth.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: とてもさわやかな青年でした。
He was a very invigorating young man.
その青年は、ぼう走ぞくの一いんです。
That young man is a member of a motorcycle gang.
どうして日本の青年は、下心があっていやらしい笑みを浮かべていることを隠そうとするのか？
Why do youths in Japan try to hide their nasty smiles when they’re up to something?
